sp.p: My love knows no time , Riki .— You were gone — how can I say ?— ages .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: It was ages , too , to me , Aoyagi .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: softeningI watched the silver stream at Kyushu — and I waited .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: What , are those tears ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Nothing , Riki — but I feel so far away — from Obaa-San .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: She can bridge the distance with her heart . A mother can always bridge all distance with her heart .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Hai !

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Our happiness is all she wants .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Our happiness —bitterly

lg.stage: He goes to her . She moves away

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: The silver fishes —

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: What has happened , Aoyagi ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Did you send the message to Obaa-San ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Did you go down the path ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Did you pass a stranger on the way ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: A stranger just came by .— He came up the mountain path .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: I crossed the stream .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Aoyagi — little sweetheart — I cannot understand .— What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Oh , Riki , Riki , I am so alone . Tell me what — why — why —

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Aoyagi , was I gone too long ? Has some demon come to you ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: No demon came . You were gone too long .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: I went down the path and crossed the stream to take a shorter way . I met a stranger —

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Singing ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Yes — I think she was singing .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: She was singing .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: What do you mean , Aoyagi ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Who was she ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: I do not know .— She said she would pass Ishiyama .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Where did you see her ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Beyond the stream — in a little glade .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Did she sing your song ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: My song ? No .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Did she know your songs ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Aoyagi ! What do you want to know ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Did she know your song to me — “ Butterfly , butterfly , alight upon the willow tree ” ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Perhaps .— I made that to you years ago — when you were a dream in my heart .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: At Ishiyama ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Perhaps .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Hai !— Obaa-San , my mother !— Oh , my heart — my heart —

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Aoyagi — what have I done ? Let me comfort you !

div.stage: He goes to her .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: You leave me nothing in all the world .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: I give you all my world .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Hai ! Hai ! Hai !

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Let me go and call the lady bound for Ishiyama .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Riki !— ah !

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Little Aoyagi — my love — she will be tender with you .— And when your tears are gone , she 'll bear your message on to Obaa-San .He goes to her , but she draws away . For a moment he is uncertain what to do ;— then — he speaks .I 'll bring her back to you .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Riki !— No !— We came up the mountain-path together — side by side .— We — but now , Riki , we go two ways .— I to Obaa-San — you to —

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Go sing your songs at Ishiyama ! Go make your poems to the butterfly .— I —

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: I have made songs only for you .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: But the songs for me are on every tongue .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Ay — I am proud of that .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: The lady at the ferry at Ishiyama —

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: She learned the song to you !

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Ah !

div.stage: Aoyagi rushes upon him and before she realizes what she is doing , she strikes him . He stands petrified a moment , then faces her very calmly .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: I shall find the stranger-woman and send her to you .— I can no longer help you .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: You can no longer help .— Oh — life — oh , love — this too short day —

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: I shall stay near at hand until you return to Obaa-San .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: I shall find the path alone .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: I 'll send the stranger-woman to you .

div.stage: Riki goes out .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Hai ! Hai ! Hai ! I watched the sunrise only yesterday and I trembled with the wonder of the dew-cooled dawn . Life seemed all peace and — today — I have known a mother 's love and my mother .— I have known a lover 's touch — love beyond love .— I am waking from a dream . The Gaki said I 'd waken — I 'd be as free as one in life . Oh , what is this thing they call life ? No happiness complete — a vision of a mountain top — a climbing to the goal — a bamboo glade — oh , the mist at Kyushu .— When I go back to Obaa-San — I shall love her so — but oh , the memory of Riki — the mountain gleaming in the sun —

div.stage: She starts sadly from the path . The Gaki enters .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Lady , I am here again . It seemed to me that I must return to you . Something seemed to call .Aoyagi almost collapsesI feed ! I feed !

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: I can not go !

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: You seem to suffer .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Oh — I have lost my way in life —

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Lost your way in life ? Let me help you .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: I have stood on the mountain side and I have seen the green valleys far below .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Talk to me — as you would to yourself .— I hear but I shall not speak what I hear .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Riki — no , I can not speak even to myself . Deep in me there is a hurt .— I can not tell —

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: A woman gives all ;— the man forgets .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: But to Riki — he knows — I brought him my full belief — my all-in-all .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Your perfect faith .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Ay , my perfect faith .— He spoke to me and then I bowed to my august lord .— I followed him without question .— And he forgets so soon .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Are you sure he has forgotten ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: You know — you saw the lady from Ishiyama .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: True .— I saw her .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: You did not meet him on the path .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: True .— I did not meet him on the path .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: He crossed the stream .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Perhaps to shorten the way .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: He met her in a little glade .— Hai !

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: What shall you do ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: I 'll go my way . I 'll return to Obaa-San .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: I 'll guide you down the mountain side .— Come , we 'll take the shorter way — the by-paths — across the stream — through the little glade —

lg.stage: She looks about once more at the scene of her happiness

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Come !

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: No , let us go down the path .— I want to see my footprints — side by side with his .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Perhaps they 're being crushed under the feet of the lady from Ishiyama !Aoyagi starts a moment as though to fly along the path before the lady comes .— She sways slowly — and then falls in a pitiful little heap .— The Gaki takes her in his arms and , utterly triumphant , starts up the mountain-side .We 'll go up — up — sweet Aoyagi , to the snow peak — gleaming in the sun .— You 'll find the mountain-top — not lost in the sky .— Your perfect faith !— Oh , you silly human — oh , futile love — climb , Aoyagi — climb without love .— But first we 'll make footprints for the lover 's eyes .— Blindness will lead him to the mists at Kyushu .— Jealousy will lead you to the lonely stars .He holds Aoyagi so that her feet touch the ground — toward the downward path . Then with a wild laugh , he turns toward the mountain top . As the laughter dies , the voice of Riki is heard callingAoyagi ! Aoyagi !... Oi !

div.stage: The laugh of The Gaki is heard once more very far away — as he ascends the mountain with his burden .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Aoyagi !— Aoyagi !

div.stage: Riki comes running in . Presently he sees the footprints .
Far , very far away The Gaki 's laugh is heard .

sp.speaker: ACT III
sp.p: Before the House of Obaa-San

div.stage: It is moonlight . As the curtain opens , Obaa-San is heard singing the lullaby ; from the distance the voice of Riki calls .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Aoyagi !— Aoyagi !— Aoyagi !— Aoyagi ! Oi !

div.stage: Obaa-San appears in the doorway .

sp.speaker: Aoyagi !
sp.p: OBAA-SANShe goes toward the voice

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Obaa-San ! Where is Aoyagi ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Where is Aoyagi ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Is she not here ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: She is not here . Where — Riki !

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: I left her in the bamboo glade — and when I returned she was gone . Her footprints pointed toward the path — and then were lost .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Why did you leave her ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: I left her because she — I left her .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: I do not know , Riki , what has come to pass — but this I know — I am waiting for her .— I am waiting for her . Go seek for her — and bring her back to me .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: I shall search for her .— Obaa-San , she —

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: I care not what she did . I am waiting here for her .

div.stage: Riki looks at Obaa-San a moment and then understands .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Aoyagi !

div.stage: He goes out . Obaa-San turns to the empty house — the empty willow tree .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: She will come back to me .

div.stage: She goes into the house . The Gaki enters .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Foolish Riki ! He searches in the valley . Mad Aoyagi ! Alone with the lonely stars !— Oh , wondrous misery that makes itself .He sees Obaa-San . She enters from the house .Good-morning , Obaa-San , my friend .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Good-morning , traveller .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Why do you rise before the dawn ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: I could not rest .— Why are you not at Kyushu ?

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: There is a mist at Kyushu — and I feared to lose my way .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Did you pass a little lady — Aoyagi , by name — alone —

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: It seems — I met a little lady .— She was not happy .— That one ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Where ?

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: I am a stranger here — I cannot say . Over there — or over there .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: She will come to me , perhaps .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Do you know her ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: She is my daughter ,— Aoyagi .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Do you not fear for her ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Perhaps .— She will be here soon .— Riki has gone for her .

lg.stage: The voices of O-Sode and O-Katsu are heard .
lg.l: This has been a restless night for age .
lg.stage: He disappears . O-Sode-San and O-Katsu-San enter

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Good-morning , O-Sode-San . Good-morning , O-Katsu-San .— The lily hands of sleep have passed you by .

sp.speaker: O-KATSU-SAN
sp.p: A strange unrest has seized upon me . I think — and think of my little one . She is glorious in my heart , and words with wings seem to flash before my eyes like fireflies in the darkness .

sp.speaker: O-SODE-SAN
sp.p: I , too , have lived in words .

sp.speaker: O-KATSU-SAN
sp.p: Obaa-San , is it not wonderful to put a joy or pain in words ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Ah , yes — if there is anyone to hear them . All my long , long years before Aoyagi came to me , my heart sang , and words freighted with my dreams and my love would come to me — here ; and they would die because they found no ear attuned to them .— Tell me what you thought , O-Sode-San .

lg.l: Shows the water grasses of the River of Heaven ,
Swaying in the cool spring air —
I know the time to meet my lover

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Every one has a poem in his heart , I believe .— What was your poem , O-Katsu ?

lg.l: Oh , messenger of the other world ,
She can not find her way —
Do you kindly take my little one

sp.speaker: O-SODE-SAN
sp.p: And you , Obaa-San ,— was it words that kept sleep from your eyes ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Ay , bitter dream-words . And for the bitterness I am paying dearly .— Over and over the words came to me : Here lies my daughter 's sleeping body On the mat beside me . But her soul is far away Asleep in her lover 's arms — And I , her white-haired mother , Hold only an empty shell . Oh , I am ashamed — ashamed .— And just now Riki came to me — and told me he could not find Aoyagi . O-KATSU-SAN AND O-SODE-SAN

lg.l: Can we not search for her ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: I am waiting here .— She may find her way back .— I would not have her come to an empty house .— Come — let 's go within — and dream that yours and yours and mine are on their way to us .

div.stage: The old women go into the house . There is just a moment 's silence — then :

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Hai ! Hai ! Hai !

div.stage: Aoyagi , utterly forlorn , enters . She looks at the house , turns and sees the mountains , covers her eyes , and drags herself wearily to the willow tree . She moans as though winter had fallen upon the world and were taunting her . The Gaki enters .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: So you have found your way — in life .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Oh , let me go back to my tree !

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: No , little Aoyagi — you would be happy then .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Let me die !

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: One can not die .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Hai !

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Where have you been ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: So far — so far !— I am weary .— When I awoke , I was on the mountain-top — alone .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Were there no stars ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Oh — the stars , the lonely , lonely stars ! I tried to touch them — they seemed so near .— I found the path — the glade — our footprints — strange people — I am here . Let me back ! Let me back !

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: And what of Riki ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: He does not care .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: And what of Obaa-San ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: What can I give to Obaa-San now — but misery ? Am I never to be free ?

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: What would you do if you were free — climb to the mountain top to see the lonely stars ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Hai !— Riki !— Obaa-San !

div.stage: Obaa-San enters . The Gaki disappears .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Was my name spoken in the dawn ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Mother !

div.stage: With a cry of joy , Obaa-San enfolds Aoyagi in her arms .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Nadeshiko ! My little girl !

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Where is Riki ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: He has gone to search for you .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Was he alone ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Alone ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Yes . Was there no woman with him — a lady from Ishiyama ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: A lady from —

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Yes — tall — fair — singing —

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: He was alone . A lady from Ishiyama —Aoyagi shudders with dreadbrought me a message in the early night —

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: It was she — young ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: No — old .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Had she seen Riki ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Yes . On the mountain-side —

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: The stranger said she was young and fair .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Perhaps the stranger did not see with honest eyes .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: He would not lie .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Sometimes the eyes and the ears lie .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: And if she had been young and fair ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Riki met her in a glade .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Did you see them meet ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: No — she was singing .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: A happy song , perhaps .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: She sang the song he made to me .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: How do you know ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Riki said she knew his song to me .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Ah , that is beautiful , that she should love his song to you .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: He —

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: My little darling , I do not know what really happened ; but this I know , you did not speak fairly to Riki or Riki did not speak fairly to you . Almost every unhappiness comes because we speak too much of our pride and speak too little of our hearts .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: I asked him if he saw her .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: A stranger told me —

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Was it the stranger you believed before Riki could defend himself ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: But , mother , I gave my all in all to Riki . He does not care .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Do you know ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: I asked Riki if they met ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Did he tell you ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: He seemed to be proud to tell .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Then he was unashamed to tell —

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: I asked him questions .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: But did you ask him the great question in your heart ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Oh —

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Did you say , “ Riki , my love , you are in all my heart . Am I in all yours ? ”

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: He told me that .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: And did you believe ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Above all the world !

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Then why doubt him later ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: The lady from Ishiyama passed by .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: My child , a lady bound for Ishiyama passed by ! Had she been singing all the love-songs of all the worlds ; had she been fairer than the lotus-flower , why should you have doubted Riki ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: A stranger —

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: A stranger !— a stranger !— Oh , why — why — why do the eyes of love grow blind because a stranger speaks ? You , Aoyagi , did not see the lady bound for Ishiyama . You did not hear her song — and yet upon the ears and eyes of a stranger you would shatter your love .— I saw the lady .— She was singing .— She was not fair .— If she had been — Oh , my little child — Riki is Riki , your august lord , the lord of your life . When he comes back , go to him and speak from your heart .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: What shall I say ?

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: I need not tell your heart .— It is only your head that can not learn to speak unprompted .— Do you love Riki ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Ay — so dearly !

div.stage: The voice of Riki is heard .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Aoyagi !

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: He is coming !

div.stage: Obaa-San , unnoticed , goes into the house . Riki enters .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Aoyagi !

div.stage: When he sees she is safe , he drops suddenly . She goes to him .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Riki , my august lord , listen to my heart .— Forget my anger .— Tell me once again that you love me .— I 'll believe .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: You know — I have always loved you .— When you were a song in my heart , I loved you so ! And now —

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Oh , Riki , can we ever forget the blow I struck ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: That was yesterday — see , this is today : the dawn has spread across the sky . What shall we do ? Look back upon the bitterness of yesterday , or try to see the fears of tomorrow , or live in the gladness of today ?

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: The Gaki of Kokoru is here at the tree . He will not let us live in happiness . He let me go with you because he meant to feed upon the misery of poor Obaa-San .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: He has not come upon us yet . We are struggling against tomorrow . This is the dawning of today .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: Then shall we live — today .

div.stage: Obaa-San enters from the house .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Come , Aoyagi ; come , Riki . We have found happiness at our door . Within there is rice and tea . Come .

div.stage: They go into the house . The Gaki enters .
Illustration : THE LADY OF THE WEEPING WILLOW TREE

sp.speaker: ACT III
sp.p: THE GAKI There is love !— Now what shall I do for misery ? Old Obaa-San remembers happiness . She has taught O-Katsu and O-Sode to remember happiness . The lovers are reunited ;— now they understand .— And I — I , ah , I must die in this dread shape and stay in this hell through all the eternities unless I bring new misery to them . What can I do ?He turns to see the treeAh — I shall kill the tree — slowly — slowly — and I 'll feed upon them all . Aoyagi is bound to the tree as one is bound to his body in a dream .— I 'll kill the tree .

div.stage: He draws his short sword and smites the tree . There is a cry from the house and Aoyagi enters quickly , followed by Riki , Obaa-San , O-Katsu-San , and O-Sode-San . Aoyagi holds her heart .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Aoyagi !She droops in his arms . Obaa-San lays her hand upon her dear child 's head . O-Katsu-San understands . The Gaki in triumph smiles again . Aoyagi cries out and shudders as she clings to RikiOh , whatever power gave strength to me and led me to my love , give me the chance to save my love .

sp.speaker: AOYAGI
sp.p: The tree !— The tree !

div.stage: The Gaki smites again .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: The Gaki of Kokoru ! Ay , I know ! I know ! I fight a fear , Obaa-San . Hold Aoyagi fast — with all your love .— I shall find the Gaki of Kokoru !The Gaki smites the tree again and again , and at each stroke Aoyagi fails more and more until she finally crumples in a heap among the three old womenAll strength ! All faith to me ! Into my hands give the power to break the bitterest hell asunder ! Into my eyes put light that I may see the cowardly fears that infest our way .— Gaki ! Gaki ! where are you ?— I pass about you and in my heart I carry fearlessness and faith .— Upon your wickedness I hurl belief .— Ah , now , I see you .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Let me go ! Let me go !

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: You shall bring misery into no more hearts !

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Ah , pity me ! Let me go ! I must feed or I shall die !

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: You shall feed no more !

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Do not let me die in this sixth hell ! Do not let me die ! Once I was human — like you and you . I came into this hell because I was bitter in life .— I made misery for others .— I put mischief in their minds .—

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: leaping upon himYou shall make no more misery .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Let me feed ! Let me live ! I can not die thus .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: throttling himDread demon , the end has come !

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Please — please — hear me .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Nay , you have made your last horror in our lives .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Riki ! Hear him — hear him .— We know not what we do , perhaps .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Then speak .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Let me go ! Do you think it did not punish me to see your misery , to bring misery upon you ? That is what these hells are . In life we can not always see what wretchedness we make ; in the hells we see and know and understand , but we can not escape our evil until we 've sucked the bitterness , the horror to the blackest end . Oh — five hells lie between me and human life . In each I may perchance forget the lesson learned before . Let me live ! Let me live !— I can not fight your faith !— Let me live !

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: What further harm will you do ?

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: I cannot help myself . I must live on you .— You are young —

div.stage: He tears himself from Riki and once more rushes to the tree . Aoyagi writhes a moment in agony . Riki leaps upon The Gaki , throttling him once more . The struggle is terrific .

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Die !

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Let me go ! Let me live !— I promise anything — I —

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Too late !— You shall harm no more !

div.stage: With one supreme effort , The Gaki draws himself to his full height and seems about to crush Riki . He leaps upon the prostrate Aoyagi and flings her body high above his head . Riki starts for him .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: I shall live ! I shall live !

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Aoyagi !

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Come not near me , Riki , or I shall crush her at your feet . I shall live !

div.stage: He laughs the hideous laugh of triumph which rang out on the mountain side yesterday .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Give her back to us ! Feed on me !

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: In your heart there is only hope and beautiful memory . Old fool , I can not feed on you .— But now in my arms I hold the precious gift by which I shall pass from hell to hell .

sp.speaker: O-KATSU-SAN
sp.p: Take me !

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Silly old woman , you , too , like Obaa-San , can not feed me . Age learns to grasp at bubbles and pretend that they are stars .

sp.speaker: O-KATSU-SAN
sp.p: But I shall dream of my little girl .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Ay , dream of her and have tender memories that are not pain .

sp.speaker: O-SODE-SAN
sp.p: I shall think of him and long for him , my lover .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: Ay , and in the memory of the firefly fete you 'll make a poem that will leave you all melting-like and holy — then where shall I feed ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: Obaa-San , are you content ? I 'll let her die at my own hand before I 'll let him live .

div.stage: He draws his dagger and leaps toward The Gaki ; but old Obaa-San is too swift for him . She catches his hand .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: Riki ! Would you kill the evil by killing the joy of us all ?

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: But the joy — my little Aoyagi — can not live so . See —

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: O Gaki of Kokoru — I stand before you , no longer a suppliant . I am old and in my years I have known all the wanting , all the hopelessness one can know in life . But in your evil way , you brought to me a moment of happiness yesterday and in that moment I saw the beauty that I had always believed must be and yet that I had never known . In your evil arms you hold the treasure of my life — you hold the songs that filled the heart of Riki . But you do not feed , oh , Gaki of Kokoru . You can not feed . Oh , Gaki , what is this sixth hell of yours ?— Who made it ? Some man who was afraid of the joy of life ;— it was too beautiful for his belief . Misery makes itself : so happiness makes itself . You stand before us , holding the darling of our dreams , but there is no misery so great as yours . See ! I stand before you — unafraid — and in my heart lies happiness .— Aoyagi rested in my arms and my breast is warm and there is a glory where her dear head lay . In my life — if you take her from me — there will be an emptiness .— There will be long silences in the days to come ; but my breast will still be warm with her touch and my ears will still hear the sweet words you cannot unsay — the lullaby I sang .— Oh , Gaki — it has been sung to her .— The climbing to the mountain gleaming in the sun — the glade where love found the perfect mystery — that cannot be undone whether we live or die .— Love that has been can never be undone .

div.stage: The Gaki looks from one to the other , but finds only that splendid happiness that is almost pain . He loosens his hold upon Aoyagi and turns to Riki with her .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: She is yours !— I have met perfect faith .— Five hells lie before me — but I have met a perfect faith .— You cannot know what wonder I am knowing . From the sixth hell I have seen a perfect faith .— I am content to die in this shape . Strike , Riki !

sp.speaker: RIKI
sp.p: I have my love .

sp.speaker: THE GAKI
sp.p: But a peace has come upon me , a peace that I have never known .— I seem to be on wings — afloat in the sky .— Stars and suns swing gently by — and cool clouds brush my brow .— Five hells lie before me .— Can it be , in each I shall find peace like this ?—He falls on his kneesNow a fire rages deep in me — a pain — I 'm torn .— Oh , Obaa-San , I die — I die .— Come to me — touch me — let me feel your gentle hands .— So ! So !— I have never known such gentleness .— Oh , I am cold — cold ! Hold me —He rises — sways — and falls . It is full day . The Gaki rises wonderfully .Obaa-San — I see — I see .— The hells were made by some man afraid of the joy of life .— It was too beautiful for his belief .— Riki — Aoyagi , there is the mountain gleaming in the morning light .— Go — see your footprints side by side .— A Gaki 's feet trod upon them , but left no mark — and they are there side by side .— O-Sode-San , I look across the River of Heaven ;— there stands your lover waiting for you — an empty boat is here to bear you to him .— O-Katsu-San ,— the messenger of the other world bears your little one upon his broad , warm back .— They are smiling , O-Katsu-San — Obaa-San —

div.stage: He points to Riki and Aoyagi . Obaa-San goes to them and lays her hands upon them .

sp.speaker: OBAA-SAN
sp.p: My little girl !— my little boy !— Today the sun is very bright . The Curtains Close .

sp.speaker: THE VERY NAKED BOY
sp.p: AN INTERLUDE BEFORE THE CURTAIN

sp.speaker: CHARACTERS
sp.p: SHE HE BROTHER The scene is half way to a proposal . A hallway with a heavily-curtained doorway in the centre . Right of this are two chairs with a tabouret between them . Right and Left are curtained arches . She enters quickly , crossing to the chairs .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: following breathlessly and almost colliding with her as she stopsGenevieve !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: with a calmness strangely at variance with her entranceWell ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Why did you —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I did n't .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I beg your pardon , you may not have known it , but you did .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I did n't .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: If you 'll only say you did n't mean it .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I did n't do it .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Now , Genevieve , you know —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I did n't .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Well , why did you —?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I did n't do it !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: meltingly but without humor or subtletyWell , if you did n't do it , dear —She is adamant .Why did you run away the moment I came up to you ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: hoping it is n't trueBut you seemed to be trying to avoid me .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: with sphinx-like indifferenceWhy should I avoid you ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Genevieve ! You make it impossible for me to talk to you .... I 'll apologise if it will help .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Why should you apologise ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Perhaps I 've misconstrued your meaning .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I did n't mean anything —He smiles pleasantly with more hope than discretion .— because I did n't do it .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Now , Genevieve , I saw you do it .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You 'll have to excuse me , Mr. Gordon , from further discussion .

div.stage: She seats herself , fully prepared for all the discussion she can force from him .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: But , Genevieve —

div.stage: He seats himself .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I did n't do it — and besides if I did what difference does it make ? I 'm free white and twenty-one .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: with a frail attempt at humorHow old did you say ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I said I was free white .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: But , Genevieve , you must admit that —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Mr. Gordon !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Please call me Henry .In his emotion he pronounces it Hennery

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I do n't see why I should .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: You did last night .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: That was different . You were Dr. Jekyll last night .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Oh , Genevieve —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You 're showing your true colors tonight .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: appealinglyI 'm — sorry —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You 're a tyrant .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I do n't mean to be . I think you 're wo —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Now do n't be personal . I 'm not interested in your thoughts .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: But , Genevieve , wo n't you tell me why you did it ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I did it because — I 've told you often enough I did n't do it .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: bitterlyJoe —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Joe — what ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Joe squeezed your hand .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Well , it 's my hand , and besides I do n't see why I should be cross-questioned by you .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: You know I 'm —

div.stage: He leans toward her and she moves away .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You 're what ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I 'm crazy about you .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Please , Mr. Gordon !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Call me Henry ! Just once .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I do n't see why I should .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Please , Genevieve .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Now do n't be silly !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Oh , Genevieve , if you only knew how it hurt me when you did it !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Did it hurt you ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I could have killed Joe — gladly .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Honest !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: You know — you must know !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You certainly are calm about it .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: in the most absurd position that hopeless love can twist a man intoWhat can I do ? I can n't be ridiculous .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Did you really see us ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Yes , I saw you .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You seemed terribly tied up with Ethel .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I had to sit by her .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I do n't see why .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I did n't have any place else to go .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I knew you were looking .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Then why did you do it ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Do n't ask me why . I loathe why .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: But oh , Genevieve , I love you so !

div.stage: He grasps her hand , not too violently . She gasps slightly , smiles pleasantly and becomes stern .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: encouraginglyPlease , let go of my hand .

div.stage: He does so . She looks at him in mingled wonder and chagrin .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Genevieve , is n't there any chance for me ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I 've never thought of such a thing . What do you mean !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I mean I love you .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: taking her scarf in his handAre n't you interested ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Why , really , Mr. Gordon , you ask such strange questions .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Oh , Genevieve — Genevieve —

div.stage: He kisses the scarf gently .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: looking at him in wonder , disappointment and delight .Do n't be silly .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: When a man 's in love he always does silly things .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Always ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Oh , Genevieve —

div.stage: He reaches for her hand reverently and this time she seems content to let matters rest .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: making conversationI have the next dance with —

div.stage: She racks her memory .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Joe , I suppose .

div.stage: He rises and crosses to the far side of the centre arch .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: drawing her scarf about her and brushing against him as she passes .Excuse me , please .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: torrentiallyYou shall not go . You shall listen to me . You have no right to treat me as a plaything when I love you so ! I love you so ! I love you so ! I think of you all day long , I lie awake at night wondering what stars are looking upon you and I find myself envying them — every one of them .She tries to speak , but he presses her head against his shoulder .I wo n't listen . You must hear me out . I 've waited days and days and days for this chance to speak to you , and you 've trailed me about like — like — like a poodle . I 'm tired of it because I love you so .

div.stage: She tries to speak again ; but succeeds only in mussing her hair .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I want you to marry me , and marry me you shall if I have to carry you away with me . Oh , Genevieve , my darling Genevieve , just know that for this moment I am almost completely happy . You are close to me and I do not feel any struggle against me . Oh , if you will only listen to me , I do not mean to be brutal . I have torn your dress . I have mussed your precious hair . But I love you so ! I love you so !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Oh , Henry — Henry — You are so wonderful !They embrace one long moment when an arm comes out between the curtains and tugs at his coat .He lets go of her as though he had been shot , turns and sees the naked arm and the top of the Boy 's head .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: whisperingGet her out of here !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Oh , Henry , Henry , have I been cruel to you ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: constrainedWe 'd better go .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: looks questioningly at himPlease let 's stay here .He presses her head against his breast and looks surreptitiously at the curtains .The Boy makes as though to get out . He starts violently — shoves the Boy back .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I saw you first — do you remember — at Poughkeepsie .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Yes , yes —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I think — I liked you then .... But I never thought you 'd be so wonderful .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Let 's gowhisperingDarling , let 's go .

div.stage: Illustration : THE VERY NAKED BOY

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: No , I want to stay here . I love this nook .He laughs nervously as she crosses to the curtains .I should love to fill it full of great tall lilies .By this time she has become lyric and swept her arms against the curtains : with a cry , rushing to him for protection .Henry , there 's a man behind those curtains !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I think we 'd better go .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Oh , Henry , you 're not going to leave him here .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: We 'd better .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: poking his head and a naked arm through the curtains .Yes , you 'd better , because I 'm going to get out of here .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Bob ! You get your clothes on !

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: I told Mr. Gordon to get my clothes .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Mr. Gordon —

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Call him Henry — just once — please , Genevieve .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: stifflyI 'll get your clothes . Where are they ?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: In my room .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: What do you want ?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Everything .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: straightening upDo n't be common , Robert .

div.stage: He starts for the door .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: No , I 'm not going .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Hen — Mr . Gordon !... Very well . I 'll go !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: No , you wo n't go either !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Please !

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Well , I 'll go .

div.stage: Boy moves as though to part the curtains . She screams a stifled little scream and both he and she rush to the curtains to hold them together .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Oh , Bob , if you wo n't get out I 'll do anything for you .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Well , I 'm cold .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Mr. Gordon , please go .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I wo n't go !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You are very strange , indeed .... I 'll go !

div.stage: She nears the door — Stops .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Never mind .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Oh , Henry , it 's Ethel .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Bob , wo n't you be a good sport ? We 'll turn our backs .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: But will everybody else turn their back ?

lg.l: Old man , can n't you see how it is ? We 're — we 're going to be engaged — and
Ethel is out there — and — and — well —

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Joe 's out there , too .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Well , yes .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Bob , I shall tell Father on you .

div.stage: She starts .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: All right , go ahead . I 'll tell Ethel .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Just wait .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: I 'll get out of here !

div.stage: Again the two rush precipitately to hold the Boy in place .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Bob , be a man ! You are childish and common . You are old enough to know better and I think it 's an outrage for you to subject your sister to this fright . We can n't go out of here just now — and you 're making it very embarrassing for us .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Mr. Gordon — there 's a cape in that closet . Will you get it for Bob .... He says he 's cold .

div.stage: He goes to the closet .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Bob , I 'll get even with you . You ought to be ashamed . I 'm humiliated .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Why — Sis ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Imagine my being with a gentleman and having a very naked boy pop into the conversation .

div.stage: He returns with the cape .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Here 's the cape .

div.stage: He tosses it over the Boy 's head and suddenly leans over and kisses her .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Why do n't you smother me !

div.stage: Boy begins to emerge .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Bob , be careful .He and She turn away .The Boy rises and as he does so the cloak falls about him until , when he steps out of the curtains , he discloses trousers and shoes .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: I can n't go through the hall looking like this .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You must .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: turningGo away , Bob . Your sister is very nervous .

div.stage: He sees the boy fairly well clothed . He gasps .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Why —

lg.stage: Turning she sees the boy fairly well clothed .
lg.l: I thought — How did you — Why did n't you — What were you doing in there ?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Father was going to get strict and keep me off the water tonight and just as I came down here to get my sweater I heard him coming to the coat room so I jumped behind the curtains and let him pass and then Joe and Ethel came in and I could n't let them see me this way . And then somebody else came and then you came in — well , I got cold .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: looking outRun on now , Bob , the hall is clear .

div.stage: Boy starts .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: What was it you did , Sis ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I did n't do it .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Why did n't you do it ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I did n't do anything .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: He said Joe squeezed your hand .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Absurd !

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Well , I hope not , because he and Ethel got engaged in here too !He and She look fondly at each other and He murmurs , “ Genevieve ” as he reaches out for her .The Boy begins to sing , “ Oh , Genevieve , Sweet Genevieve , ” and they become aware of him , turning upon him and pursuing him with a warning cry of “ Bob . ”

sp.speaker: ACT I
sp.p: JONATHAN MAKES A FRIEND

div.stage: The scene represents the lumber room in the carriage house on John Clay 's suburban estate . The room is crowded with old trunks , paintings , barrels , boxes , chests , furniture showing long residence during slow epochs of changing taste . Everything is in good order and carefully labelled . At the right of the room is a door opening onto the stairs which lead to the ground floor . A small window is set high in the peak of the gabled end up centre . At the left a chimney comes through the floor and cuts into the roof as though it had been added by Victorian standards of taste for exterior beautification . An open stove intrudes its pipe into the chimney . The single indication of the life of today having touched the place is the studied arrangement of an old rosewood square grand piano . The keyboard is uncovered . On the top is a tiny theatre — a model masked and touched with mystery , according to early adolescent standards . Two benches stand in front of the piano , and the piano stool is meticulously set in place . A flamboyant placard leaning against the music rack announces :

sp.speaker: TODAY
sp.p: ZENOBIA A tragedy in ten acts by Alexander Jefferson , Sr . The light in the room is dim , although it is quite bright out of doors . There are two low windows which are heavily barred . The little theatre is so arranged that when the manipulator stands on the box to work it , his head can be seen over the masking . The curtain rises disclosing an empty room . Presently laborious steps are heard on the stairs and a key is turned in the lock . Then Aunt Letitia enters followed by Susan Sample . Aunt Letitia is a motherly old woman who has been in the Clay home for many years . She may have preferences , but like the buildings on the estate , she stays where she is . Susan Sample is a tall , slender girl of fourteen with a very gentle manner and a way of looking at people that indicates a receptivity rarely met in one so old . Letitia goes to one of the trunks marked E R in large white letters and unlocks it .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Here they are , my dear . Help me with the hasps .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: What does E. R. really stand for , Mis ’ Letitia ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: E. R .... That 's a secret , Susan , that little girls are n't supposed to know .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: I wo n't tell .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: But what good would that do , my sweet ? Please open the windows .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: opening the window and returning to her questionNo one would know you told me .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: I would know . Yes , I would know that I had told somebody else 's secret .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Whose secret is it ? Please .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: I 've been living in this house for thirty-five years , Susan , and I 've known the secrets of all the boys and girls from time to time .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: You know mine , too .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: And I 've never told one of them , either .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Does old Mr. John ever have secrets ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Old Mr. John ! For shame !... Of course he has secrets .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: I wish I knew some of his , Mis ’ Letitia .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: My dear , you never will know them . John is very quiet .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Who in the family did n't have any secrets at all ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Oh , they all had secrets when they were young . Nathaniel had fewer than any of them and ...

div.stage: Her words are lost tenderly in a memory .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Why has n't he ever come back home ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: as she busies herself with the contents of the trunkThat is his secret , Susan , and we must n't ask too many questions . Nathaniel is coming today . I wo n't ask any questions .... He was a fine young man . Yes , he 's coming back today , my dear . He was the baby of the family .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: How old is he now ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: You little chatterbox ! Between you and Jonathan I have to fight to keep anybody 's secrets .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Does Jonathan ask many questions ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: When we 're alone he does . He 's just like his Uncle Nathaniel . God bless him !

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: seeing a costume in the trunkOh , is n't that just wonderful !

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: holding the costume up for Susan to seeThat is what you can wear in the pageant , my dear Susan .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: taking the costumeOh ! Oh ! Oh !... I wish I knew whose it was .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Would that make it any prettier ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: No , but I 'd like to know just the same .... Was it E. R .' s ?

div.stage: A cry is heard outside , “ Aunt Letty ! Aunt Letty ! ”

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Oh , Susan , it 's Nathaniel ! It 's my boy . Here I am , dear .

div.stage: She has an armful of costumes which she drops nervously .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Mis ’ Letitia , I believe you love him best of all !

lg.l: No , I do n't , but I always understood him , I think .
lg.stage: The voice below calls again , “ Where are you ? ”
lg.l: Come up here , my boy . Come up to the lumber room .

div.stage: Steps are heard on the stairs , young eager steps , and Nathaniel Clay bursts into the room . He is an eternally young man of thirty-five , who has touched the dregs and the heights of the world and remained himself .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: taking Letitia in his arms , then holding her from him as he inspects her .Aunt Letty ! Not a day older .... But oh , so wise .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Nathaniel , my boy , my darling , darling boy .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Now , now . Do n't cry .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: My boy , my boy . My splendid boy .

div.stage: Susan has forgotten her costume in her admiration for Nathaniel . She puts it down on the bench in front of the piano .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: And this is —

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: This is Susan Sample .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Not —

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Yes , time has been flying , Nathaniel . This young lady is Mary Sample 's daughter .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: How do you do ? I can n't believe it . You were only a little pink cherub up there in the sky when I ran —

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: hurriedly interrupting himYes , Susan was born three years after you went away .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Oh !... And , Aunt Letitia , you 've opened Emily 's trunk !

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Yes , Susan is going to be in a pageant .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Who was Emily ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: She was —

lg.l: Nathaniel dear , you must not satisfy her curiosity .
You go find Jonathan , dear , and tell him that his uncle is here .
I 'll put these things away , and we 'll go into the house .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: reluctantlyGood-bye , Mr. Clay .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Good-bye , Susan . You 'll come back , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Oh , yes . Good-bye .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: Susan goes out .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: She hates to go . She 's never seen anyone just like you : and I have only seen one .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Who 's Jonathan ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: He 's the one .... He 's Emily 's boy .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You mean Emily —

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: No , no , my dear . Emily was married , left the stage . She was n't happy . The boy was her only comfort .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: He 's my nephew . Why , I 'm Uncle Nathaniel . Oh , Aunt Letty , I 'm getting to be an old man !

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Nathaniel , Jonathan does n't know about his mother . I sent Susan away because I did n't want her to associate these things with Jonathan 's mother .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: My God , Emily did n't do anything wrong .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Well , she was an actress .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: And a good one , too .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Yes , yes , dear . All that has been talked over many times , but John is the head of the family and he does n't approve of the stage .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: So ! John is still himself .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: John is austere , Nathaniel . He is a Clay through and through and he holds to the traditions of the family .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I remember the traditions , Aunt Letitia .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: I never oppose John . He feels that he is right . But it is very hard sometimes to live up to his rules .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Has he rules ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Well , he has ideas , dear — much like your father 's . We might call them rules .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Where is Emily ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Two years ago , Nathaniel .

div.stage: There is a moment 's silence .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Did she ever go back to the stage ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: No . John forbade it .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: And John is still forbidding .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: John is the head of the family .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: So .... The Clay family is still an absolute monarchy .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Nathaniel , dear , will you promise me —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: with a smileI 'll try .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Will you promise not to antagonize John ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Will John antagonize me ? I came back to see my home — to see you , my dear aunt . But I am a grown man now .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Wo n't you try to be patient ? It will be pleasanter for me . And I have waited so long to see you , Nathaniel . There are seventeen very , very long years for us to talk about . Let John have his way .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Well , I 'll try for a few days . But I give you warning , my ideas have been settling during the past few years , too .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Remember , he is used to being obeyed just as your father was .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Yes , I remember that , dear Aunt ; but John is n't my father . He is just a brother to whom fate gave a fifteen years ’ start by birth .

div.stage: As a voice calls , “ Nathaniel , are you up there ? ” Nathaniel looks at Letitia .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: His voice is just the same .CallingYes , John , I am up here .The antagonism between the two brothers is apparent immediately .John Clay enters . He is an austere , pompous man of fifty who has the softness of the tithe-collector and the hardness of the tax-collector . He speaks with an adamantine finality which is destined to rude shattering .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How do you do , Nathaniel ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I am very well , I thank you , John . How are you ?

div.stage: They shake hands perfunctorily .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You arrived ahead of time .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: We have n't met for seventeen years .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No . I 've been away , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Where have you been ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I shall be here for two weeks , John , and if I should tell you all about myself today , I should have nothing to talk about tomorrow .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: severelyYou have n't changed , Nathaniel . You are still frivolous .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I shall be serious when I am your age , brother .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I came out here to ask you to be very careful of your conversation before the children .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: The children ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes , my two grandchildren .—

lg.l: Grandchildren ! My , that makes me a great uncle . I am getting old , Aunt

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I do not care to have them or Jonathan hear about any revolutionary or other unusual ideas .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I shall try not to contaminate the children and Jonathan . How old are the children ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mary is four and John 3rd is two .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I shall try to spare their sensibilities .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: They may not understand you but they will hear .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: to LetitiaHow old is Jonathan ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Fourteen .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: The impressionable age .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: The silly age .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Brother John , no age is the silly age . Fourteen is the age of visions and enchantments and fears . What a boy of fourteen sees and hears takes on a value that we cannot underestimate . Most men are defeated in life between fourteen and twenty . At fourteen a boy begins to make a lens through which he sees life . He thinks about everything . Ambition is beginning to stir in him and he begins to know why he likes things , why he wants to do certain things . He formulates lasting plans for the future and he takes in impressions that are indelible . Things that seem nothing to old people become memories to him that affect his whole life . The memory of a smile may encourage him to surmount all obstacles and the memory of a bitterness may act as an eternal barrier .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nathaniel , are you a father ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No , John , I am only a bachelor who is very much in love with life in general and one lady in particular .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You can know nothing of children , then .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I remember myself . Most men forget their younger selves and that is fatal .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: One would think to hear you talk that the most important things in life were a boy of fourteen and his moorings .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: One might know it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You are still the same impractical theorist .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I am the same theorist — a little older , a little more travelled . The trouble with you , John , is that you think no age is important except your own . You always thought that , even when you were fourteen . Oh , I know I was n't born then , but I know you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Did you come back to your home in order to lecture me ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No , no , I beg your pardon . I came back to see my home and Aunt Letitia and the children — and you , and I — I think — Jonathan .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nathaniel , when your letter came telling me that you had decided to come back to see us , I was going to ask you not to come —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I gave no address .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But on second thought , I made up my mind to forgive you —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: To let bygones be bygones .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: That is the better way , brother : let the dead past bury its dead .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why did you run away from home ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Because we could n't agree , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I was older than you ; my judgment was mature ; I was the head of the family , in my father 's place .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: We did n't speak the same language . I wanted something out of life that you could n't understand ; that my father could n't understand . I determined to get it by myself .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: And so , I ran away .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Leaving no trace , no word .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Oh , yes , I left a very important word — “ Good-bye . ”

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You were willing to leave all the work of our father 's business on my shoulders .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You were willing to take it all . And I wanted my freedom .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You were selfish and heartless .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Selfish ? Because I had my life to live and meant to live it ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You should have told us where you were living .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I preferred to work out my salvation alone , without interference . My going away gave you a free hand . John , do n't tell me that you were not overjoyed that my flight gave you all my father 's fortune .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It was my duty as head of the family to protect you .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I did n't ask for protection . I wanted understanding .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: A boy of eighteen must not be allowed freedom .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Perhaps not , John , but he must be allowed to grow toward his goal . Eighteen is not too young for a man to fly through the air in defense of his country , or you . The burden of the world today is on the shoulders of men from eighteen to eighty , share and share alike .... I wanted to be a writer —

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: And our brother Henry wanted to be a musical composer and our sister Emily wanted to be an actress ! A fine putout for the leading commercial family of this state !

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Well , John , our brother and our sister have paid the final penalty . They have died . Henry left a handful of worthless little tunes and Emily left a trunkful of costumes as monuments to their folly . And now Emily 's boy is here under your wing .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He 's a dreamer like all the rest of you .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: with interest ; tenderlyYes ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He spends all his leisure time playing with that fool toy there .He points to the model theatre .Nathaniel smiles and crosses to the piano and lifts the cloth that covers the theatre ; then he looks at the placard and laughs joyously .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: “ Zenobia . ” " Alexander Jefferson , Sr . ”

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He pretends that 's his name — Alexander Jefferson , Sr !

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: People like to have other names . Look at all artists — like writers , pugilists , and actors , and base ball players . And the Sr. Is an effort to appear older .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , I 'm breaking him of all that nonsense . I allow him only a certain number of hours for play . Emily used to spoil him and it 's been a task to conquer him .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Jonathan is fourteen . When I was fourteen — What are Jonathan 's tastes ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He reads all the time and he wants to write plays and poetry ; but I am conquering that silliness .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I think I am going to like my nephew . John , I 'll come into the house shortly . I think I 'll look at this toy a moment and I 'll get Aunt Letitia to show me some of Emily 's things . A mere matter of sentiment .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Now do n't put any foolishness into the boy 's head .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I promise you I sha'n ' t try to change the boy 's head , brother .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I play golf from five to six .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Oh , you 've taken up athletics ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: The doctor 's advice . Will you join me ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Thank you , no .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Very well . I 'll see you at dinner .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Thank you .John goes out . Nathaniel looks musingly at Letitia who has been sitting silently on Emily 's trunk , knitting , Nathaniel crosses to her and sits on a stool at her feetDoes John always talk to you so much , little church mouse ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: I have been a poor relation for thirty-five years , my boy , and to be a successful poor relation , one must learn the art of silence .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No wonder I ran away !

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: But you should have written to me .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Perhaps — I should — yes — I should have written , but I did n't . You see , Aunt Letty , I was a sensitive boy . All my life I had dreamed of doing my own work . I saw Henry disappointed in life , I saw Emily made miserable enough through the traditions of the family . John could n't understand me and I could n't understand him . There was no common meeting-ground . John was the head of the family and so deeply was the idea of submission to rule ingrained in me that I could think of only one way out of my restraint . I would n't study engineering , and I would n't continue at Somerset School . Well , I ran away from my ancestral castle to find my way in a new world . I think I have found it .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Jonathan does n't want to study engineering , either .

lg.stage: Looks closely at her a moment and then smiles

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Poor Jonathan !

div.stage: At this moment Jonathan enters the room . He is a slender boy of fourteen with a deep problem in his eyes . When he smiles before his elders , which is seldom , he seems always prepared to restrain the smile . His voice is just changing and this adds to his reticence . He has a tremendous capacity for expressing wonderment and , as usual with one of his type , he is capable of great displays of temper . He gives the impression of thinking about everything he sees . He is at the age of wonder and only custom prevents the world from becoming the promised land of visions and enchantments .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Poor Jonathan !He turns and sees the boy .The two stand face to face for a moment . For Nathaniel it is the first moment of a new relationship . For Jonathan it is a moment of uncertainty . He has heard himself called “ Poor Jonathan ” and he is facing another male relative . Jonathan looks first at Letitia , then at Nathaniel and then at Letitia .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Jonathan , this is your Uncle Nathaniel . Nathaniel , this is Emily 's boy .

lg.stage: Holds out his hand which Jonathan takes very shyly

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: How do you do , sir ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: How tall you are !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: quite conscious of his short trousersYes , sir .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I did n't take you away from any studies , did I ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No , sir .... I was just writing something when Susan called me .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: May I ask what you were writing ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir ....

div.stage: He swallows .

p.stage: Looks quickly for some indication of laughter in Nathaniel 's eyes

lg.l: It 's a tragedy , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: In ten acts .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: There may be only eight .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Then I know who you are !Jonathan looks at him in surpriseYou are the celebrated dramatist , Alexander Jefferson , Sr .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Did Aunt Letitia tell you ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No , sir . I read it on the billboards .Jonathan laughs with a catch in his breathAnd I should like to attend a performance , Mr. Jefferson .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: It is n't finished yet .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Well , when am I to see this theatre ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Your Uncle Nathaniel and I shall come together .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You 've seen all the plays .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: That does n't make any difference . I 'd like to see them again .

div.stage: Jonathan looks at her to be sure she is in earnest . Then he smiles .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'll finish Zenobia for tomorrow .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Agreed ! Can you get the scenery ready ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I painted it last week .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: You must have the orchestra , too , Jonathan .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , ma'am . Susan has some new pieces .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Is Susan the orchestra ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: What else have you written ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: A lot of plays , sir . Mother and I used to write little plays . I do n't write many any more .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm getting too big .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Do you ever write anything beside plays ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: That 's splendid . Stories ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .... And I 've written some po — poetry .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Excellent !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: They 're not very good , but Susan always wants me to write the poetry for the music .

div.stage: Aunt Letitia has repacked the trunk and locked it . She sees that Nathaniel and Jonathan are getting on famously .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: I 'll go to the house now and you can talk to Jonathan , Nathaniel .Jonathan looks appealingly at Letitia , but with a smile she goes downstairs .Jonathan and Nathaniel look at each other for an embarrassed minute , then Jonathan takes refuge at his theatre .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: May I see some of your plays ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do you really want to see them ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Yes .

div.stage: Jonathan goes to a box on the piano in which there are many manuscripts carefully bound . He hands one to Nathaniel .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Here is one that mother and I wrote . She loved the theatre .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: taking the strange-looking little manuscript . Reading :“ Robin Hood and His Merry Men . ”

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: We used to make all those old stories into plays .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Do you like to write ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Oh , yes . I wish I could write real plays , but there 's no one to help me now . My mother used to correct them and tell me what was wrong . She knew a lot about the theatre and she used to tell me all sorts of things . But now Aunt Letitia does n't say anything . Sometimes she comes to a show , but she can n't help me . And Uncle John does n't like the theatre . He thinks I 'm too old to give shows , but I can n't help it . There 's nothing I like so much .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: May I read this some time ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .... Would you like to see it played ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I want to see them all .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Forty-one of them ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Forty-one of them ! Where do you keep them all ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Here in this box .

div.stage: He shows all the manuscripts .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: What are the pink ones ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Those are the ones mother liked best and these —showing blue onesare the ones I liked best .... I like them all now , but it used to be lots of fun to choose our favorites .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: What is this one that 's different from all the rest ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: That 's one that mother wrote all by herself . It 's best of all .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You must save these carefully , Jonathan — all your life .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Oh , yes , sir .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Some day you may be proud of them .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: See — she wrote this , and I wrote this . I was a bad writer , was n't I ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: What do you want to do , Jonathan ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You mean what do I want to be ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I want to write plays .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Is that all ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Well , I 'd like to run a theatre .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: What else ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'd — you wo n't tell anyone , will you ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Of course not .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You see , Uncle John wants me to go to Somerset School to study engineering and learn the business .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: And you do n't want to — Is that it ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'd rather be a writer .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: They say you can n't make any money at writing .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: That 's what Uncle John says , but I want to just the same .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: If you follow John 's advice , you 'll be a rich man .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'd rather be poor . What would you do , Uncle Nathaniel ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I — why I 'd — Oh , come now , Jonathan — you know John is the head of the Clay family and you and he must decide this question .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Would n't you want to be what you want to be ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Perhaps I should .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I do n't see how anyone can decide what you want to be — no matter how old he is .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Have you ever talked to John ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Oh , yes , sir .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: What did he say ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: He said I had to study engineering or go to work in the factory next fall for good .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: What do you want to do ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I want to go to a fine prep school and then to college and then —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Then what ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I want to be an actor ! !

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I see .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do n't tell anybody .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I wo n't . That 's pretty far from engineering , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir . But everybody can n't be alike . You and Uncle John are n't anything alike .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: And we 're brothers , too .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do you ever get all mixed up and do n't know what to do ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Oh , yes . I think everybody does .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: What do you do then ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I do something very silly .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do you do silly things , too ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Yes . I 'm afraid I do .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: What do you do when you get all mixed up ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I 'll tell you — it might not work with everybody , you know — but it works with me .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir !

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: My mother used to sing me a song called — “ There is a green hill far away . ” I always liked that song because it gave me a feeling of contentment and happiness . I imagined that I could see that hill with its pleasant green slopes and at its foot lay a little cottage all cool and pleasant and open to the winds . There were no locks and bolts to keep one out or to keep one in . I used to imagine that I was climbing that hill to the top of the world and when I reached the summit I could see —

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: enthralledI know — the whole wide world .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Its very bigness made me happy in my imagination .... Then when I grew up and heavy troubles came to me I remembered the Green Hill Far Away and one day I found such a hill and I climbed it — clear to the top — and there below me lay the world — the whole wide world — and I told the world something then and felt the better for it .... Jonathan , there is nothing like a hilltop to make a man feel worth while .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I know what you mean .... But I always want to jump when I look down from any place , do you ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I suppose everybody does .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Uncle John thinks every boy ought to be alike .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Many schools used to think that way .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: But boys do n't all think the same . They 're different just like men , only they do n't know so much .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Perhaps not .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Uncle John wo n't let me put on long pants until I 'm fifteen .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: He let me put them on when I was fifteen , too .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Were you as tall as I am ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Just about the same height , but my legs were like pipe stems and I was very much ashamed .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: So am I .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You 'll forget all about it after you 're fifteen .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I can talk to you like I used to talk to my mother .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Thank you . We 're going to be fine friends , are n't we ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You bet . Is it silly for me to like to write plays ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Why do you ask that ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Because Uncle John says it 's silly .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Well , it all depends upon the way you look at it , Jonathan . The world has never been able to agree as to what is and what is not silly . Mr. Browning , the poet , might have considered hooks and eyes the silliest things in the world ; but to Mr. de Long , they were , no doubt , the most important things in the world . Many men agree with Mr. Browning and many ladies agree with Mr. de Long .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: That 's what I think .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You and I probably have many thoughts in common .

div.stage: Susan and Mlle . Perrault enter . Mlle . Perrault is a Frenchwoman of exquisite grace and poise . She speaks English fluently , but with a charming accent and an occasional Gallic phrase larding her pleasant sentences . Her entrance into the room is electric . She has already won Susan .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Ah , there you are , Mr. Nathaniel Clay . I met la belle Susanne in the roadway and she told me you were in the lumber room in the carriage house and I say to her , “ We shall track him to his lair . ” Besides , I want to see what a lumber room is .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I was hiding from you .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Villain ! And this is Jonathan . How do you do ? Susanne tells me you write poetry and she writes music and she promise me that you will sing for me .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I can n't sing .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Ah ! Susanne tell me you have a theatre and you write plays and paint scenery and write poetry and sing songs and she say if I come here to the lumber room in the carriage house you will play me a tragedy and sing me a song .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Having introduced yourself to everybody , will you tell me , Susan , how Mlle . Perrault learned so much in such a little time ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Well , I was waiting for Jonathan to call me .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Oh , I forgot .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: She was sitting like a little fairy in the grass by the roadway , and I stop my car and ask for Mr. Nathaniel Clay and she say you are here in the lumber room in the carriage house and she tell me many things — because we like each other very , very much and we walk very , very slowly .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Now ! Now that you know all about Miss Susan Sample and Mr. Jonathan —He realizes he does n't know Jonathan 's second nameI think I shall introduce you by your pen name , Jonathan — Mr. Alexander Jefferson , Sr .To Mlle . PerraultI am going to let them know about you . This , lady and gentleman , is Mlle . Marthe Perrault of Paris , France . Mlle . Perrault , may I present my friend Susan and my nephew Jonathan ?

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: falling into the moodI am very , very pleased to see you again , Miss Sample . It is a great pleasure to have the honor of meeting you , Mr. Alexander Jefferson , Sr . I am looking forward to the premiere of your great tragedy , Zenobia , of which Miss Sample has been telling me .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Puts her arms about Mlle . Perrault and Jonathan is uncertain whether to be happy or afraidHe wrote lots of others , too .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Forty-one .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I think I 'll tell you two a secret .Susan pricks up her earsDo you like secrets ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: And can you keep them ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Oh , yes , sir .

lg.l: Well , some day Mlle . Perrault is going to be my wife .
Mlle . Perrault shows her engagement ring .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: When ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Very soon . She is here on some war work and when she and her father go back to France I shall follow and we shall be married .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Ooh —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Now you must n't tell .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Honest .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No , sir !

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Now , we have a secret . And you are going to sing me a little song .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Come on , Jonathan . Let 's do the new one .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Well , I 'll try .He is quite miserable with stage-fright .Susan sits at the piano and plays a chord . Then Jonathan begins to sing with much fear in his voice .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: singingAll on a summer 's day , With flowers by the way , A fair young prince and his purple knight Found a princess at her play . So by the crescent moon He asked a royal boon And sat him down on a soft green knoll — And the night-time came too soon .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
