sp.p: Oh , that is just like a little French peasant song ! How does it go ? La — la — la — la — la — la .Susan begins to play it again .Jonathan sings more surely than before . Slowly Mlle . Perrault falls into the rhythm and very simply dances a little peasant dance to Jonathan 's and Susan 's song . The two youngsters are in the seventh heaven of delight . So — when one is very happy or very sad , he makes a song and when he 's very , very happy , he dances . And when he is very , very , very unhappy he dies . You see , I am very , very happy . When do you play Zenobia , Mr. Jefferson , Sr .?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'll have it ready tomorrow , maybe tonight .

lg.l: We shall have a season ticket . But now , I want you to meet my blessed Aunt
Letitia . She has n't changed one bit in all these years .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: To Aunt Letitia then . Good-bye , Jonathan . Tomorrow is the day of the great premiere .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: awkwardlyThanks .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: And la belle petite Susanne , au revoir .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: I 'll walk with you part of the way .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Very well . Marchons , marchons ....

div.stage: They go out .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: holding back a littleGood-bye , Mr . Manager .He goes out calling “ Marthe . ”Jonathan is left alone in his joy . As he stands , a strange , aimless , vacuous whistling is heard outside the window an though from one ambling by . Jonathan hears it unconsciously , moves to put his plays away , alternately whistling and singing “ All on a summer 's day . ” Presently the whistling of the strange air is heard as though coming from downstairs . It stops and a voice calls out “ Hi ! ”

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Who is it ?

sp.speaker: VOICE
sp.p: It 's me .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: What do you want ?

div.stage: By this time the Voice has become a person in the shape of Hank , one of the scum of creation who asks nothing of life and gives nothing . He was born of woman and he grew into man 's form , but one looking at him wonders how he survived dirt and the mere effort of breathing . He is stoutish with no marked coloring unless it be a cross between khaki and field-gray . Weather and time have conspired to render him inconspicuous . When he speaks his voice is produced with a careful effort to conserve energy . When he walks it seems to be a movement in answer to prayer rather than a physical fact .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Say —

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: How 'd you get in here ?

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Well , it 's this way , you see . The gate was open out there and this looked pretty fine to me so I come in .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You 'd better go away before my uncle sees you .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Look here , young feller , I ai n't goin ’ a-do no harm .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Well , he does n't allow strangers on the place .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: I jus ’ come in to ask if I could sleep somewhere around here if I worked for my sleep and grub .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No , he wo n't let you .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: How do you know he wo n't ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: ‘ Cause it 's a rule .

div.stage: Hank whistles a snatch of the strange air and sits down .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Where 's your pa ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: He 's dead .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Long ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Ten years ago .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: How old are you ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Fourteen .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Your pa died when you were four . So did mine .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Did you ever have an uncle ?

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: How many you got ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I got two living and one dead .

lg.stage: He whistles a snatch of the strange air and takes a chew of tobacco .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Is about to become impatient , but an innate tolerance causes him to answerShe died when I was twelve .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: So did mine .WhistlesWe 're alike in lots of ways , ai n't we ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: What did you do when your mother died ?

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: I felt pretty sorry .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Did your brothers and sisters help you any ?

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Have you any brothers and sisters ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No —

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Me neither .Whistles casuallyNo one took no notice of me .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: What 'd you do ?

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: I went away .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Why did n't you try to work ?

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Could n't find nothing suitable . ‘ T first I felt sort o ’ worried an ’ then I kep ’ walkin ’ on and I seen so much trouble where I went I says to myself , “ Hank , you 're lucky , ” I says . “ You ai n't got no fam'ly to bother you an ’ you ai n't got nothing to worry you an ’ you do n't have to get no place in partic'lar and you do n't have to stay no place . ” A man wot 's got a wife 's all the time worrying about her health or her money spendin ’ or her gaddin ’ or her naggin ’ . An ’ a man w'ots got a fam'ly ' s always wondering where they 'll end . An ’ a man 's wot 's got a home 's all time worrying about keepin ’ it locked up . I bet the poor nut wot owns this place can n't breathe easy for bein ’ scared things 'll be took or burnt up . W'y you — look at you —WhistlesYou 're wishin ’ I 'd go ‘ cause you 're ‘ fraid I 'll take somethin ’ . I wo n't take nothin ’ , young feller , ‘ cause I do n't need nothin ’ now and I wo n't need nothin ’ till it 's cold again — and then I 'll git an overcoat maybe . It 's too much trouble takin ’ things — ‘ cause you have to carry ‘ em .WhistlesYou goin ’ to let me sleep here some place ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I can n't . My uncle would drive you away . Maybe he 'd have you arrested .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: I ai n't done nothin ’ . I ai n't hurtin ’ nobody .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Well , he does n't allow strangers around .

lg.l: That 's where I went by jus ’ now .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I heard you whistling .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: That 's a tune I made up once .Whistles

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do you make up tunes ?

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: That 's the only one I ever done . It comes in handy and it do n't hurt no one .

div.stage: Jonathan unconsciously tries to whistle a phrase of the tune .

lg.l: No , that ai n't it . It 's this way .
Jonathan tries it again and fails .

sp.speaker: No . Here
sp.p: Jonathan makes it this time .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: That 's it . Say , what you got these bars for ? It 's like jail . Are they afraid you 'll jump out on them rocks ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No , I guess not . There is n't much danger of my wanting to jump out .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: You never can tell for sure , young feller .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: It 's to keep people from climbing in .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: There ai n't no bars over that one .Pointing to gable window

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: That 's too high .

lg.l: It 'd be like fallin ’ off the top of a house , would n't it ?
Jonathan whistles “ All on a Summer 's Day . ”

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: What you got there ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: That 's my theatre .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: A show ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: How does it work ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: These are the actors .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: What 's the string fer ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You put him in a groove and pull him .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Lemme see it .

lg.l: All right . I 'll show you a scene from the play I 'm going to play for my

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Fire away .

div.stage: Jonathan lights the lamps that are back of the screen and pulls the blinds or some cover over the barred windows .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: I would n't have all this junk if you 'd give it to me . No , sir , when I move I carry my house with me and there ai n't much o ’ that now .Indicates his clothes

lg.l: All ready . Now you sit there .
He goes behind the screen and taps some bells .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: What 's that fer ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: That 's to get ready .

lg.stage: Jonathan opens the curtain and discloses a scene from Zenobia .
lg.l: That 's beautiful . It 's just like real .
lg.stage: Jonathan pulls a figure across the stage .
lg.l: Hello , old man . That 's the one I jus ’ seen . Where 's the string ?

div.stage: Jonathan lifts the string .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Here it is .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Now where 's that feller goin ’ to ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: coming out from behind the screenWell , you see , Zenobia —

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Zenob — God , what a name !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: They used to have names like that .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: How d ’ you do it ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Look , I 'll show you a little .

div.stage: He goes behind the screen and closes the curtain .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: What you doin ’ that for ? I like to see that picture .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm going to show you how I do it .

div.stage: Jonathan rings the bells .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: All right . I 'm ready . Let her go .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: in assumed voice“ Hail , noble duke . ” “ All is well , I ween . ”

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Say , are they talkin ’ to each other ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Which is the noble duke ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: pulling a stringThis one .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: And the other one 's name is Iween , ai n't it ?

sp.p: No , his name is Rollo .

lg.l: All right , fire ahead . I guess you know what you 're doing .

sp.p: in assumed voice“ Hail , noble duke . ” “ All is well , I ween . ” “ Not very well , noble duke . ” “ What is wrong ? ” “ Queen Zenobia is very mad , noble duke . ” “ What is she mad about , Rollo ? ”

div.stage: Uncle John enters suddenly .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: I 'm seein ’ a show .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You get out of here this instant .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: I ai n't hurtin ’ nothin ’ , mister , but I 'll git out if you say so .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What do you mean by this , Jonathan ?

lg.l: I 'll git out . Thank you fer the show , boy .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: calling after HankCome on , get out of here quickly .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: offI 'm out , mister .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Now , Jonathan , what do you mean by bringing such people into this place ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I did n't bring him in . He came up while I was working .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Do you call that silly stuff working ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I was getting it ready for Uncle Nathaniel .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He 's been putting that nonsense in your head , has he ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: He asked me to let him see all my plays .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I suppose he told you to ask that dirty tramp in here .

lg.l: No , sir . He did n't see the tramp .
John crosses to one of the windows and opens it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: callingYou get away from there . Move on .

sp.speaker: HANK 'S VOICE
sp.p: I guess the roadside 's free , mister .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: We 'll see about that .

div.stage: Hank whistles .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Jonathan , I wo n't have you waste your time on this stuff . I 've been pretty lenient with you and I 've allowed you to keep your toys because Emily spoiled you ; but you 're too big for such things and I 'm going to put my foot down right now . I 'm not going to have this silly stuff around .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Uncle Nathaniel does n't think it 's silly .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I 'll decide what is and is not good for you .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: The same thing is n't good for everybody .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Do n't talk back to me , young man .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 've got a right to think .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Jonathan !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: If my mother was living , she would n't call everything I like to do silly .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Your mother did n't know what was good for you .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: My mother was the best woman in the world .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That will do , Jonathan . Your mother was my sister and I am not saying anything against her . But I do say that stuff must go .

div.stage: He starts for the door .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: If this theatre goes , I go , too . I 'm not —

div.stage: John walks over to the theatre and sweeps the whole structure onto the floor .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Now .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You dirty coward , you —John turns upon the boy and strikes him across the face .In mingled rage and humiliation Jonathan sobs wildly once or twice , then controls himself and glares violently at his uncle .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I 'll let you think about it . I 'll leave you here with your toys like a girl-baby .He goes out the door , closing it and turning the key in the lock .Jonathan runs to the door .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You let me out of here ! You let me out of here !He pounds the door with his fists .Then he turns in despair and humiliation . He paces the floor a moment , not knowing what to do . Suddenly Hank 's whistle is heard . The boy listens as though fascinated and goes to the window and watches Hank . Jonathan goes to his wrecked theatre and , taking it up , piles his manuscripts , the pink and the blue , on it . He hesitates to include one in the pile , offering once or twice to put it in his pocket , but he finally places it in grim determination with the others . Then he takes it off and stuffs it in his pocket . He stuffs the pile in the stove and sets a match to it , watches it a moment , then writes on a piece of paper , fastens it to the door . Then he finds a piece of rope on a packing case , moves the ladder under the gable window , fastens the rope to a peg in the wall , climbs the ladder , considers a moment , returns to the stove with the beloved manuscript , stuffs it in the fire , remounts the ladder and lets his weight onto the rope . As he disappears from view , the rope breaks and a cry and sound of falling are heard . The flames from the burning theatre and manuscripts flicker against the wall for a silent moment . The key is heard to turn in the lock and John and Nathaniel enter .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Jonathan !

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: He 's hiding .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Jonathan !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What does it say ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: “ Good-bye !... Jonathan . ”

lg.l: Did you tell the silly boy about your running away ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I told Jonathan nothing about myself . You are the head of the Clay family and out of custom I respected your position ; but , by God , John , you 're a failure with this boy .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He —

div.stage: Hank enters carrying Jonathan in his arms . Jonathan is limp and pitiful . His clothes are torn . He is moaning pitifully .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: He fell on the rocks out there .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Put him over here .

div.stage: Hank places Jonathan on the bench near the piano . Nathaniel places the costume , which Susan left there , under his head for a pillow .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What was he doing ?

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: He was —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: This is no time for questions , John . Call a doctor .

div.stage: Jonathan moans and rolls his head , looking vacantly at Hank now and then .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: moaningGood-bye .... Jonathan .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: We 'd better take him in the house .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: My mother was the best woman —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: He 'd better stay here until the doctor comes .

div.stage: John exits .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: All on a summer 's day —

div.stage: All the time Nathaniel has been passing his hands over Jonathan .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: He 's out of his head , ai n't he ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Perhaps , but sometimes one 's heart speaks in a delirium .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: He acts like his back 's broke .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: My back 's broken , Hank .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Listen , he 's saying my name . We wuz pals , sure nuff .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: My back 's broken , Hank .

div.stage: Curtain .

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: Six years have elapsed since Act I as years elapse in a boy 's imaginings .

Throughout this act the characters are disclosed without reason as in a dream ; and the movement of the act represents four terrors of a delirium — anxious effort to make oneself known , a feeling of fetters , climbing and a sudden fall .

p.stage: Before the curtain rises the voices of Jonathan , Hank , Nathaniel and John are heard , muffled and far away .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: He fell on the rocks out there .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Put him over here .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What was he doing ?

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: He was —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: This is no time for questions , John . Call a doctor .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Good-bye .... Jonathan .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: We 'd better take him in the house .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: My mother was the best woman —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: He 'd better stay here until the doctor comes .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: All on a summer 's day —

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: He 's out of his head , ai n't he ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Perhaps , but sometimes one 's heart speaks in a delirium .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: He acts like his back 's broke .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: My God — his back !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: My back 's broken , Hank .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Listen , he 's saying my name . We wuz pals , sure nuff .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: My back 's broken , Hank .The curtain has risen unnoticed .A faint light that grows steadily brighter as light does when one comes out of a swoon discloses Jonathan and Hank seated on a log at the left of the stage , where the bench had been . Jonathan seems much older , and he is crooked and dirty and unkempt , and Hank is somewhat brutalised , less negative .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: My back 's broken , Hank .

div.stage: Hank looks at him .

sp.speaker: Tired ?
sp.p: HANK

lg.l: I think Uncle Nathaniel would help me if he saw me .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: He could n't do nothin ’ for you . You can n't straighten a crooked back ....

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Hank , I 'm tired of this and I 'm going back .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Going back where ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm going back home .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Your Uncle John wo n't let you in .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Uncle Nathaniel will take me in .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: He ai n't there no more and besides he wo n't know you .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Honest — do n't you think he would ?

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Sure , he would n't .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I wish I had n't run away .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: If you do n't quit wishing I 'll run away from you .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You would n't leave me , would you , Hank ?

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Sure , I 'd leave you .... What do you think I am — a wishing stone ?... I want peace , I do .... An ’ your wishing 's disturbing my peace .... Every day fer six years you squeal about what you done .... Your Uncle John swatted you and you burned your theatre things and jumped out o ’ the window and broke your back and I saved you ....

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I can n't do anything with a broken back !

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: What do you want to do anything for ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Sometimes I 'd like to write a little .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Go ahead .... I 'll wait for you .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: And I 'd like to give a show . You know , Hank , I used to want to be an actor ....

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Sure , all kids want to be actors or go in a circus or do something where a lot o ’ people are lookin ’ on .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: But I can n't be an actor now , because nobody 'd want to look at me .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: You act like that hump 's ruined your life , when all you got to do 's crouch over a little more and look sad and you can get anything you want . Why , it 's money in your pocket , that 's what that hump is ; it 's money in your pocket .He closes the conversation by whistling .Say , go on over to that house and get us something to eat .Jonathan prepares for the quest and Hank rolls over to go to sleep .As Jonathan crosses , lights disclose a hill with pleasant green slopes . At its foot stands a little cottage , all cool and pleasant with great glass doors . There are no locks and bolts to keep one out or to keep one in . A high plaster and brick wall flanks the cottage . As Jonathan nears the cottage he meets Uncle John , whose austerity is more apparent than ever . Jonathan cowers a moment , then attempts to smile .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Hank said you 'd turn me away if I came back .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Were you talking to me , boy ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm so sorry I ran away , Uncle John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Uncle John ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do n't you know me , Sir ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Indeed I do not .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm Jonathan —

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Jonathan ! My nephew Jonathan ?— Ha ! Ha !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do n't you remember I did n't want to study engineering — I did n't want to go to Somerset School ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Where is Jonathan ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm Jonathan , sir . You remember I jumped out of the window and I tried to run away .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You seem to know a lot about it . Where is Jonathan ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I tell you I am Jonathan .... Do n't you remember you struck me — You struck me across the face — that 's what made me run away .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I should have whipped him and put him to bed .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I would have run away just the same , Uncle John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Do n't call me Uncle John !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: But you are my Uncle John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ask you where is Jonathan .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Would you like to see him ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I should like to know what has become of him .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Would you let him come back home ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No . When he ran away , I cast him out forever .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Could n't you forgive him if he was very , very sorry for what he had done ?... Could n't you forgive me , sir ?... I am Jonathan . Honest I am Jonathan .

lg.l: Do n't try to deceive me . Jonathan was impudent as you are ; but he was a
Clay : he was straight and fine .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: But I broke my back .

lg.l: Tell me where Jonathan is , you imposter .
lg.stage: He takes Jonathan by the arm and twists it brutally .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I do n't know .... Let me go .... I 'm not Jonathan .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Tell me ....

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: in desperationHe 's dead .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: He 's dead . He died somewhere .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: And so you tried to palm yourself off as Jonathan .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm sorry .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Do n't you know you can n't make your way with lies ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You ought to be whipped , but I suppose you do n't know any better . I should have you arrested for vagrancy .Jonathan winces .But I wo n't . I pity you , you dirty little beggar .He starts to walk .You ought to wash your hands and face at least .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Please , sir — one minute .... How are Mary and John third ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mary is ten — a big girl — and John third is eight — a strapping boy who will be a great help to me .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: And — how is Aunt Letitia ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My aunt died of a broken heart .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: A broken heart ?

lg.stage: Jonathan buries his face in his arms .
lg.l: There ! Do n't cry for someone you 've never seen .... Here , here , take this —
lg.stage: He presses a coin into Jonathan 's hand and goes out .
lg.l: Jonathan looks at the coin , then after John , and seems to close his heart .
He crosses to the sleeping Hank .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Here , Hank .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: taking the coinWhat 'd he say ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: He did n't know me .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: I guess you 're not going back home now !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No , I have n't any home .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Then quit your snifflin ’ an ’ go on over to that house .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: All right , Hank .Hank curls up and goes to sleep again .Jonathan crosses to the cottage and finally summons the courage to knock on the door . As he does so the lights within grow bright and disclose a lovely little room with a beautiful piano in the centre . In a moment a young woman appears and opens the doors . It is Susan Sample . She is charmingly older ; but she is dressed almost as she was in the old lumber room .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Please , Miss — why —

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: What do you want ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I — do n't you know me ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: No , I do n't know you , little boy . What do you want ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I — do n't you really know me ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: I 've never seen you before .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I know you .... You 're Susan Sample .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Who told you ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm —He becomes conscious of his backWhy Jonathan told me .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Have you seen Jonathan ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Where is he ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: He ran away . Why does n't he come home ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Because — oh , I do n't know .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Who are you ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm a vagrant .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Are you hungry ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: looking toward HankNo . I 'm not .... I 'm not begging .... But will you do something for me ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Yes , if I can .

div.stage: Illustration : JONATHAN MAKES A WISH

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Oh , yes .... What shall I play ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Anything .Jonathan notices his dirty hands .Excuse me a moment .He goes to a bird-bath and washes his hands , wipes them and returns to the piano .Susan plays a bit of a nocturne with ease and grace .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do you remember this ?

div.stage: He hums “ All on a Summer Day . ”

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Oh , yes .

div.stage: She plays the tune in a sophisticated musical way , but Jonathan is disappointed .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: You do n't like it ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: That is n't exactly the way it goes .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Oh , yes , it is .

div.stage: She plays it once more and sings it .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No — no — no . It ought to go this way .

div.stage: He sings it as he had sung it years before .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: You sing that just as Jonathan used to sing it .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I like it that way .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Did Jonathan teach it to you ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes .... A long time ago .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Did he tell you —

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: About the lovely lady who danced to the tune ? Oh , she was wonderful !

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Jonathan ran away — and he never wrote to me or thought of me .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: He thought of you and he talked of you and he sang of you .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: No .... I can n't believe that .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Jonathan loves you very much .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: If a man loves a woman very much he can n't go away from her for years and years .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Suppose Jonathan had pride and was ashamed to let you know that he had failed .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Jonathan would n't fail . I know Jonathan .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: He — Susan Sample !

div.stage: Susan plays softly . She is lovely in the sunlight which is lengthening across the lawn .
Jonathan watches her quietly . The love of the boy fans into flame and he reaches out to her , then in the consciousness of his deformity he turns away .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Will you tell me where Jonathan was when you last saw him ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I do n't know — The last time I saw Jonathan — he was tall and straight — and making his way .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Oh , well .

div.stage: Albert Peet enters . He is a little man of immaculate appearance and great preciseness .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Ah , Susan .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Albert , you are late .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Who is this ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: This is a friend of Jonathan 's .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Jonathan who ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Do n't you remember Jonathan who had the toy theatre ? He ran away from home .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Oh ... and this is his friend ? How do you do ?

lg.l: Do you remember this ? I used to play it for you .
lg.stage: She begins “ All on a Summer 's Day . ”
lg.l: Jonathan and I made it up .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: laughingOh , yes .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: to JonathanCome on and sing it .

div.stage: Jonathan is not sure of the status of Albert Peet .
Susan plays and she and Jonathan sing with great feeling .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: looking at his watchWell , all this is very pleasant indeed , but we 'll have to go , Susan dear .

div.stage: At the “ Susan , dear ” Jonathan turns quickly and sees the two holding hands . Susan holds up her left hand and shows an engagement ring on it . Jonathan is utterly crushed .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I think I 'd better say good-bye .

div.stage: He takes up his cap .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Good-bye . If you see Jonathan , tell him I 'm going to marry Albert Peet . He 'll know .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Good-bye .Albert and Susan walk off happily in the sunshine .Jonathan looks after them . Mlle . Perrault enters followed by Mary and John 3rd . Mlle . Perrault 's dress is almost like the one she had worn when she first met Jonathan in the lumber-room , except that the colors are reversed and more brilliant . Mary is a lovely little yellow-haired child of ten and John 3rd is a stoical matter-of-fact boy of eight . The two children are evidently very fond of Mlle . Perrault , as fond as Jonathan and Susan had seemed . If the children seem thoughtless and cruel , it is because they are children and life has not yet laid a hard hand upon them . The sun rays are very low against the wall now so that anyone walking near it will cast a very heavy shadow .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: John , look — he 's a hunchback .

lg.l: Jonathan turns and seeing Mlle . Perrault smiles .
How do you do , little man .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I am well , I thank you .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: What are you doing here ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I am with Hank .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Hank ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , Hank 's my pal . There he is — asleep .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Oh , what a dreadful person .... Children , do n't go near him .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: He 's not so bad .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: But he is a vagrant — a tramp . Why does he do nothing ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: He 's happier that way .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Are you his son ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Oh , no .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Where is your mother ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: My mother 's dead .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Where did she live ?

lg.stage: Looks for a trace of recognition

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Oh , please tell us .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'd better not .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You ask him , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: Uh-uh !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: I do n't want to know .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Why do n't you want to tell us ? We wo n't tell anybody .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Nobody 'll believe me .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You see , I ran away from home —

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: When you run away from home , you 're no good .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Now , John , that is n't always so .

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: It is .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: It is n't . Goldilocks and the Babes in the Wood and the Marquis of Carabas were all good , and they ran away from home .

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: But they had bad homes .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Was your home bad ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I thought it was .

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: You thought it was . But was it ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: Then you 're no good .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Oh , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: No , he is n't . Grandfather said nobody who ran away from home was any good !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Why did you run away from home ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I must n't tell .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Oh , you wo n't tell anything !

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: pointing to HankWhat did you say he was , Ma'mselle ?

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: He is a vagrant —

sp.speaker: MARY AND JOHN III
sp.p: What 's a vagrant ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Ooh —

div.stage: Puts up her hand to make a wish .

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: Aw , I 'm not going to make a wish . Grandfather 'll get it for me anyway if I want it .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Is that Mary Clay and John Clay ?

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: They do n't remember Jonathan , do they ?

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: You mean Jonathan who ran away ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Who 's Jonathan ?

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: He 's David 's friend . I know that . And he was very good .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: What do you know about Jonathan ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I knew him once —

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: He was a splendid little man ! He could make such lovely songs .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do you remember the one he and Susan Sample made up ?

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Let 's see — how did it go ?

div.stage: Hums a little — tries several folk tunes . The children edge up to Jonathan during this and manage to touch his back several times , each keeping count . Jonathan smiles at them , thinking it 's attention .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No , it went this way .

div.stage: He sings a little of the song and Mlle . Perrault joins him . As he stops singing she switches the time to waltz time and begins to sway to it . The music is taken up as by a dream-orchestra and Mlle . Perrault dances a very lovely little waltz .

lg.stage: Mlle . Perrault turns and sees her shadow on the wall .
lg.l: I can make a bigger one than that .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Oh , come on , ma'mselle , let 's all make shadows .

div.stage: The three of them stand in front of the wall .

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: Boy , you come , too .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Come , boy .Jonathan joins them standing so that his deformity does n't show in the shadow .Now , let 's dance — Give me your hand — so .The four dance , while Mlle . Perrault hums “ All on a Summer 's Day . ” They are having a very good time when Susan and Albert enter .Jonathan is a little conscious of Susan and Albert , and he manages to make several awkward moves .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Now , let 's make everybody 's shadow dance by itself .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Oh , come on .

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: You first , Mlle .

lg.stage: Mlle . Perrault stands before the wall and makes a very lovely shadow .

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: I wo n't . I 'm going to be next to last .... He 's going to be last .

div.stage: Mary makes a pretty “ statue . ”

lg.stage: John III , holding a staff , stands bow-legged and pigeon-toed .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: to John IIIYou little Jackanapes ! You !

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: to JonathanYou can n't do that .

div.stage: Jonathan , still conscious of Susan , but more in the spirit of the game nevertheless , laughs almost gleefully .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You just wait .

div.stage: He stands in front of the wall and does some comical movements with his feet and legs , then he turns in such a way that for the first time the shadow of his hump is thrown into a pitiful distortion on the wall . He does n't see it at first , for he is lost in the game with the children .

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: yelling suddenlyOh , look !

div.stage: The children laugh immoderately , and Jonathan turns his head quickly , but in so doing alters the shadow . He smiles joyfully and then once more falls into the distorted picture .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Ooh —

lg.stage: Jonathan turns his head this time and sees the full horror of the thing .
lg.l: Mlle . Perrault and Susan have realized too late to protect Jonathan .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: John ! Mary ! Tell the little boy good-bye . We must go .

div.stage: Jonathan looks toward Susan and Albert . There is pity in Susan 's eyes and a smile in Albert 's .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Albert , come — let 's go !

div.stage: They pass into the house .

lg.l: Was n't he funniest of all !

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Now , run along , children . Run along .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Look , I can make a hump-back .

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: So can I .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Not a good one !

sp.speaker: JOHN III
sp.p: You can n't touch mine .

div.stage: He smacks Mary on the back and runs off , Mary following him .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Little man , I 'm very sorry . You must n't let them hurt you . They are only children .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .... Thank you .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: May I do something for you ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No , ma'am ... if you please ... I must go to Hank .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: Here , take this —

div.stage: She offers a coin .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Oh , no , ma'am ....

div.stage: He puts his hand behind him .

sp.speaker: MLLE . PERRAULT
sp.p: I am sorry .... Very , very sorry .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .Mlle . Perrault goes out silently , and in a moment she is heard to call “ Marie ” — “ John , ” and a distant answer is heard .Susan comes to the door and sees Jonathan . She crosses to him . He looks at her almost with madness in his eyes .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: They did n't mean to hurt you .

div.stage: She lays her hand on his arm .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , I know .There is a moment of the tenderest , most understanding silence . He turns away .Susan starts to reach in her bag , she even takes her purse out ; but she replaces it unopened , and instead of bestowing alms , she takes a flower from her hair and presses it in Jonathan 's hands . He looks at her with years of pent-up gratitude loosed from his heart . Silently , she turns away and goes into the house . Jonathan , left alone , turns so that his hump once more shows in the most distorted shadow . He lifts the flower and for a single moment , its shadow rises above the shadow of the hump , a tiny cross on his little Calvary . Then he lays the flower against his cheek and sits upon the log near Hank .

sp.speaker: Hank awakens
sp.p: HANKlooking up stupidly

sp.speaker: What you got ?
sp.p: JONATHANhiding the flower

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do n't you call me that !

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: So — ho ! What you yelling at me for ?

div.stage: He sits up .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Nothing .... I did n't mean to yell .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: What you got there ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I tell you I have n't got anything , Hank .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Come on . Come across .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: It 's not for you .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Come on .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Gimme it here ....

div.stage: He grabs Jonathan and tears the flower from his hand .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Stop that !

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Great God !Throwing the crushed petals on the groundSay , what 's the matter with you ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I tell you , I 'm going back .... I 'm going back to my home .... I 'm going to find my Uncle Nathaniel . I know he 'll take me in . He wo n't blame me because I 'm a cripple .... I know .... I know .... Did n't he say , “ Poor Jonathan ” ?...At this moment Nathaniel enters , and the two stand face to face as they had stood in the lumber-room at their first meeting .Hank slinks away . Nathaniel is untouched by the years . Jonathan looks at him hopefully , but there is no glint of recognition In Nathaniel 's eye .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: timidlyUncle Nathaniel .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: What did you say , my boy ?

lg.stage: Less and less audible , as his disappointment increases

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I can n't hear you .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You — are — my — Uncle Nathaniel .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Come , come , my boy . I can n't hear you .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Are n't you — Mr .— Nathaniel — Clay ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: kindly , but as to a strangerYes , I am Mr. Nathaniel Clay .

div.stage: Jonathan smiles one of his old half smiles .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: My name 's — Jonathan .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Jonathan !... I had a nephew whose name was Jonathan .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do n't you know me ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You must forgive me , little man — but I do not remember you . Boys grow so quickly .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do n't you remember Zenobia ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Zenobia ? Who was she ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do n't you remember the little theatre ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Oh , yes , my nephew Jonathan had a little toy theatre , and he wrote a play called Zenobia .... He burnt them .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Was it wrong to burn them ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I do n't know . You see Jonathan ran away , and I have never seen him since .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do you blame him ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Well , I can n't say . When a fine boy like Jonathan runs away from home , he may have what he considers a good reason .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do n't you know why he ran away ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I think I know .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Would you tell me why ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: That would n't do any good , my boy .... If you had an uncle who liked you very much , would you run away ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No , sir — not if I had another chance ....

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do n't you really know me ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I 'm sorry — no !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: pointing to HankDo you know him ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: That tramp ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .... That 's Hank .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Hank ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , the one I ran away with .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Did you run away , too ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir ; I jumped out the window , and I fell and broke my back . Hank said —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: What a dirty man !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: He 's my pal .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You 're evidently a fine young man inside .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Oh , I 'm sorry , sir , that I ran away .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You can n't undo the past , my boy , but you can make the future .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I can n't straighten my back .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Perhaps not , but you can straighten your life .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm only a beggar , sir .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: There is something everybody can do .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: There is n't any place for me ....

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: My boy , there is a place for everybody who wants a place .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do you remember what your nephew wanted to do ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Yes , he wanted to write plays and run a theatre and be an actor .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I could n't ever be an actor , could I ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No , my boy .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Supposing you had your heart set on something and could n't do it , what would you do ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I 'd not give up .... I 'd try something else .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Supposing I were your nephew , what would you do ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I 'd find out what you wanted to be .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do n't I look like Jonathan ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Jonathan must be very tall now .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: If Jonathan were n't tall ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: But he is tall and splendid . I know Jonathan ! And he 's doing what he set out to do .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I hope you 'll find him , sir , and I hope he 'll make you proud .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: very earnestlyMy boy , how old are you ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm twenty .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Twenty .... Will you try to pull yourself out of the rut ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: What do you mean , sir ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Look at that man . What is he to you ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: He 's my pal .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You must n't waste your life on such emptiness as his .

lg.l: I 'm going to try , sir .... And if I make good , will you believe I 'm

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I 'll believe you are you .... Here ....

div.stage: He offers Jonathan a coin .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Oh , no , sir .... I can n't — from you —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Well , you are a strange beggar —

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm not a beggar at heart .... I do n't want to be what I am . But I do n't know which way to turn . I 'm all mixed up .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: All mixed up ?Nathaniel turns and looks toward the hill .Boy , there is a green hill far away . Climb to the top of it , look about and you will see —

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I know : the whole wide world !

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Exactly .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Go to the hilltop alone — and cry out to your heart 's content .— There 's nothing like a hilltop to make a man feel worth while !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I knew that , sir ; but I forgot it . I 'm going —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Good-bye , boy ; God bless you .

div.stage: The two clasp hands and Nathaniel goes .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: He believes in me ....

div.stage: He watches Nathaniel with wide eyes , then calls to Hank .

sp.speaker: Hank ! Hank !
sp.p: HANK

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Who did n't know you ?

div.stage: Hank lies down .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Uncle Nathaniel .... He just passed by .... But , Hank , he believed in me ! He believed I 'd make good .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Say , what 's the matter with you today ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm goin ’ to leave you , Hank .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Huh ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Old pal , I 'm going to leave you forever . You 've stuck by me —

lg.l: Ai n't you saved me a heap o ’ trouble ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: But I 'm going now , Hank . Good-bye . I 'm going to the green hill far away .He starts away leaving Hank alone and asleep . The lights fade out .Soft music is heard through the darkness and slowly the outline of the green hill appears close at hand . Jonathan outlined against the sky appears at the edge of the hill , climbing with difficulty .

lg.stage: The voice is heard with the music
lg.l: Nine ninety-nine — one thousand . You 're nearly there , Boy .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Nine hundred and ninety-nine — one thousand — I 'm almost there .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: far awayA thousand and one — a thousand and two —

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: A thousand and one , a thousand and two — I am here !

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: far awayThe world is here .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: as though addressing the worldListen .... I ran away . I ran away . I was fourteen . I saw visions of great things . I heard voices of the past and the future . I wanted to tell what I saw and heard .... Oh , you who made sport of my dreams , I am here at the top of the world ! Uncle John , I have heard things you will never hear , and I have seen things you will never see .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: far awayBut your back 's broken .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Oh , Susan — Susan Sample — see — see . I told you I was n't a beggar . See — see — Jonathan stands at the top of the world !

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: faintlyBut your back 's broken .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Oh , people of all the world , I am a boy who asks you to hear me and to understand . I only wanted to work out my way .... I planned my way because I could n't help it — I wanted to build my own world — alone .... I climbed clear to the top — Jonathan stands before you —

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: Jonathan 's dead .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Dead ?... Oh , see the wreck of everything .... Jonathan is dead !

div.stage: He falls .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Boy — boy — Jonathan !— I believe you are you .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Uncle Nathaniel !He rises slowly .Oh , people of all the world , my Uncle Nathaniel understands .— I speak for all the boys of all times . Have patience — patience and understanding . Do n't you remember when you were young ? We come to you with hopes and dreams and wishes and fears ,— and these are the things that life is made of —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I am here , Jonathan .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm coming to you . I 'm coming back to you with all my hopes and dreams .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: We 're waiting for you , Jonathan .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 've made my wish that 's coming true ! !

div.stage: He jumps into space .
Curtain .

div.head: ACT III

sp.speaker: JONATHAN MAKES A WISH
sp.p: The scene is a summer house on the estate of John Clay . It is charmingly furnished with wicker chairs and a table . The building is hexagon shape and we look into half the hexagon . The doors at the left open on to the path that leads from the house . The doors at the back open onto a garden path that leads to a gate . Eight weeks have elapsed since the first act .The curtain rises disclosing an empty stage . It is early evening and sunset is leaving only the faintest tinge above the hills . After a moment Jonathan enters . He is unchanged except that he still carries in his eyes some of the horror of his delirium . He opens the back windows and then sits above the table and begins to look at an illustrated paper . Nathaniel enters carrying a manuscript . He seems a bit less carefree than at his homecoming , and he also seems closer to Jonathan .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Well , my boy —

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Uncle Nathaniel , did you know that Caproni was an artist ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You mean the Caproni who makes the wonderful aeroplanes ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No , I did n't know it ; but I 'm not surprised .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Are n't these pictures fine ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Excellent .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: He made them .... They 're like great dragon-flies , are n't they ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: A whole swarm of them .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: It must feel funny to fly through air .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Would you like to try it some time ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes ... but I 'd have to get used to it .... It must be like diving .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: When you were very ill you seemed to imagine you were falling .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Did I talk much when I was unconscious ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You talked almost continuously .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Did I ?... You said you 'd tell me what I said — when I was strong enough .... I 'm pretty strong now .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Do you know what I did ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: showing manuscriptCan you guess ?

lg.l: “ Jonathan Builds a Fear . ” What does that mean ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: When you were delirious I listened to what you said and then I made a story out of it .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You mean this is all about me ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: It 's about a little hunchback who thought he was you .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I know . I was always trying to make somebody know me , and finally I thought I jumped from the top of a hill and I seemed to be falling for years and years ....

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Those were terrible days , my boy , and do you know , we were afraid you would n't live .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: It was a terrible feeling .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I know , but all that 's over now ; and there 's the whole story about the little hunchback you never were .

lg.stage: Hank 's whistle is heard . Jonathan rises very quickly and looks at Nathaniel .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: He comes every now and then to ask about you and to get something to eat .

div.stage: Hank whistles again .

sp.speaker: HANK 'S VOICE
sp.p: at backHi !

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Come in , Hank .—

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Is the old man here ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm well now . How are you ?

lg.l: I 'm beginning to get cold , so I think I 'll go south tomorrow and I thought
I 'd drop in to say good-bye .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I 'll give you an overcoat , Hank .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: No , thanks . It 's too hot to carry it . I 'll get one when I really need it , maybe .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Well , here 's something for you .He offers him a five dollar bill .Five dollars ! No , thanks . If I had that much money I 'd lose it maybe . Give me two bits and call it square .Nathaniel hands him a quarter .Thanks .... Well ... good-bye .... I 'm glad your back was n't broke .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Good-bye , Hank .

sp.speaker: HANK
sp.p: Good-bye , Mister .... I 'll see you next year maybe , when it 's warm .— Say , kid , I 'd like to see that Zenobia show again :— “ Hail , noble duke , ” “ All 's well , Irene . ” “ Not very well , noble duke . ”He goes out , chuckling to himself .Aunt Letitia enters . As usual she has something to keep her hands busy . She seats herself comfortably in a chair that custom has evidently made her very own . In her work she shows the effect of time upon her eyes and she may feel a tiny draught that causes her to close the doors behind her and draw her scarf a bit more closely about her . Never has Aunt Letitia seemed more successfully the poor relation .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: I thought you were out with John .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No .

div.stage: Jonathan is looking at the manuscript .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: to JonathanHow do you feel , dear ?

lg.l: Fine ;... I think I 'll go in the house and read this .
I 'm glad it is n't true .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: It 's the story of his delirium . I thought it would interest him — and relieve him .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Has John gone ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Only for a stroll — the doctor 's orders .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Sit down .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: In John 's chair ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: If you wish .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: John 's chair ! The throne of the head of the family !He sits in John 's chairWell ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Nathaniel dear , you are making John very unhappy .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: And John has made me very unhappy , dearest Aunt Letty .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: The feeling at the dinner table was almost unbearable tonight . There we sat strained and silent .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I am sorry . I try to avoid meals with John as much as possible .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: You 've been here eight weeks and John and I know nothing of you . For me it is enough that you are here ; but John is the head of the family and he feels that you ought to treat him with greater deference .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: It is revolting to me to have a tsar in the family .

lg.l: Your father and your father 's father and grandfather were rulers of the

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I do n't question that .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: You can n't change John .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I do n't want to change John .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Then why not tell him something about yourself ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: It is none of John 's affairs how or why I live . It is none of his affair how or why or when I shall marry Mlle . Perrault .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Perhaps not .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: When I tell him anything , Aunt Letty , it will be one thing — I have stayed here because I love Jonathan , because he needs me . And I have listened to the boy 's fears and to his hopes as they came out of his poor tortured little soul in his delirium . I have watched him during his convalescence , and I see in him a growing man in prison . John sees in him only the potential head of the family ; but he is my flesh and blood as much as he is John 's and I intend to set him free .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: My beloved Nathaniel , John will not give Jonathan up to you .

lg.l: I do n't want Jonathan unless he wants to come to me , but I do want

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Is n't he a bit young to have freedom .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Aunt Letitia , I do n't mean a silly license .— I mean freedom . If you are cultivating a peach-tree you do n't expect oranges on it even if it could wish to be an orange tree , but you can help to make it bear better peaches . Jonathan is n't a mechanical business person . His bent is in another direction .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: What are you going to do ?

lg.l: All I know now is that I shall stay here until I find a plan .

div.stage: Jonathan enters .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Where is Uncle John ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: He has gone for a stroll .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: What do you want , my dear ?

lg.l: Uncle John sent word that he wanted to see me here at 7 : 30 .
lg.stage: Letitia and Nathaniel look at each other .
lg.l: Jonathan takes out a large silver watch .
John will be on time — count sixty slowly —

div.stage: John enters . He is rather pale , seems pre-occupied and even more unapproachable than ever .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Did you have a pleasant stroll ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I was n't walking .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: I shall go into the house , I think .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No , Aunt Letitia , I would rather you 'd wait , if you please .Nathaniel is an interested spectator . He cannot understand why Jonathan should be present for what will probably be an eventful family scene .Nathaniel , will you sit down ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Certainly .— Where ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: tartlyWould you like my chair ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Thank you .

div.stage: He sits in John 's chair , much to John 's annoyance .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Jonathan , sit down .Jonathan sits . John also sits . Aunt Letitia knows what to expect . Nathaniel is more curious than angry . Jonathan is attending his first family conference .Jonathan , I 've sent for you because I want to talk to you seriously .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Do you think the boy is strong enough ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: The doctor told me today that he would be quite equal to it .... Eight weeks ago , Jonathan , you made an effort to run away from your home , because I punished you . In your foolish defiance of all family authority you suffered a fall that might have resulted in a lasting and serious injury . Fortunately you have recovered fully from the result of your fall .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Excuse me , John , but all of us know this .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: One moment , please , Nathaniel .... I have now arranged that you begin your preparation for your life work immediately . You will leave for Somerset School the day after tomorrow .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: desperatelyUncle John , I do n't want to go to Somerset School .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You will leave for Somerset day after tomorrow . Good night , Jonathan .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Why Somerset ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Good night , Jonathan .

div.stage: Jonathan , dazed , goes out .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Jonathan will never go to Somerset School .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nathaniel , you forfeited your rights in the family councils when you ran away from home seventeen years ago .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: This boy will run away again and again and I mean to save him from what I have suffered , if I can .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nathaniel , by what right do you attempt to interfere with my decisions ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: By the right of blood and understanding .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Blood and understanding ? Where were you when Emily had to leave her husband and brought her boy into my home ? Where were you when Emily died ? I took Emily in and I took her boy in . As head of the family it was my duty to do so and as head of the family it is my duty to see that the boy is brought up in the best traditions of the family .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: John , you can n't force this boy into a mold .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: A boy of fourteen does n't know his mind .... Do you know what Jonathan wants to be ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Yes , a writer of plays , a theatre director , and an actor .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Imagine !... And I suppose you encouraged him .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No , but I did n't discourage him . The selection was wide enough for him to find some lasting life work .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He never told me he wanted to be an actor .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Oh , my brother , every growing boy has a deep secret wish that he cannot bring himself to disclose ! As you know , I always wanted to be a writer , but most of all I wanted to be a left-handed base ball pitcher . And although I 'm irretrievably right handed I used to practice — religiously — pitching with my left hand .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That was juvenile foolishness .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Yes , but it was genuine .John starts to speak .What am I now ? I am going to tell you , John — by and by . First , we must dispose of the boy .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I shall decide about the boy .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No , John ; the boy must decide for himself .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He 'd decide to be an actor .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: If he did , what of it ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I want members of my family to do useful work .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: What is useful work ? An actor serves his purpose just as a plumber or lawyer serves his .... The only difference is that all of us are not plumbers or lawyers while all of us are actors . Yes , John , we 're all playing something — you are playing at head of the family , I 'm —

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Still I do not regard acting as a worth-while or lucrative profession .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You never know , John .... Five generations ago the Clays were respectable carpenters . They were n't wealthy and they gave no promise of becoming wealthy . Then suddenly our revered ancestor became a successful maker of cypress drain pipes — sewer pipes , I think we used to call them ! The family fortunes were founded !! Our ancestor bought a high hat and the esteem of his neighbors . Cypress was in time replaced by pottery . Conduits for wires and terra cotta building materials were added to our achievements and then in your regime superfine sewers became a specialty .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Every kind of concrete work !

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I beg your pardon ! Concrete sewers and other concrete things .— Such is the foundation of the family .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You are evidently ashamed of our business .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Not at all , but I cannot consider the manufacturing of sewers a greater achievement than acting .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nathaniel , are you an actor ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What are you ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: For the present I am Jonathan 's uncle .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You have nothing to do with Jonathan .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: The boy is not going to Somerset School .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nathaniel , I shall not tolerate your interference . Now I must ask you to leave this house .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: John ... Nathaniel ... my boys , it is n't my way to interfere ; but please for my sake , for your mother 's sake — think what you 're doing .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With some tenderness he lays his hand on Letitia 'sI have thought , Aunt Letitia . I can not allow this boy 's life to be ruined as Emily 's and Henry 's and Nathaniel 's were .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Ruined ? John , I 'll tell you how ruined my life has been and I 'll tell you in terms you 'll understand . My income last year was over $ 350 , 000 !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Are you acting now ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Yes , I 'm acting — I 'm acting in terms that you will understand .... You know that I 'm your brother Nathaniel . Do you know who else I am ? I am a writer and a playwright and a director in the United Baking Company and a stockholder in the National Munitions Company — munitions , John ; think of it , millions , millions in them — and I 'm willing and eager to take Emily 's boy and educate him in the way he wants to live his life .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What are these heroics ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I mean what I say . If need be I shall use brute force , financial force or any kind of force to free Jonathan from the misery that I endured in this house .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You had everything you wanted .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Everything except freedom to think my own thoughts . John , some people are like reinforced concrete . Someone builds the iron frame and the wooden molds , then pours the cement and when it has hardened , the molds are removed and lo , you have a monolith — a solid unchangeable stone .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You talk very well , Nathaniel , but I shall insist upon bringing up my sister 's child in my way .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Would you have him run away as I did ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He will never run away again . He has had his lesson .

div.stage: Jonathan enters carrying a suit case .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: May I speak to you , Uncle John ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What are you doing with that suit case ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm going away .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Who gave you permission ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Nobody .... I 've been thinking since a little while ago and at first I thought I 'd run away again ; but that would n't be quite fair — so I came to tell you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Take that suit case back into the house .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No , sir ! I 'm going and nobody can keep me here unless they tie me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , I 'll tell you one thing — if you leave this house without my permission I 'll cut you off without a penny and you 'll never be allowed to come back again .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir . I know that ; but I 'm going and I came to tell you good-bye .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Very well . You 've made your choice — and I never want to see you again as long as you live . Good-bye , Jonathan . Good-bye , Nathaniel .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: John , do n't say things you 'll regret . Jonathan does n't mean what he 's saying .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes 'm , I do mean what I say .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Good night .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: Boys , you are so hot-headed — so much alike ....

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You dear , you have always been content to compromise while we two must go our own ways or not at all . You go to John . Help him as you can . He 's not a bad man — he 's just a structure of reinforced concrete . You love John and he in his way loves you . Go to John and comfort his outraged authority .

sp.speaker: LETITIA
sp.p: I 'm sorry things have turned out this way .She kisses themGood night , my dears . Wait until morning if you can , my darling Nathaniel .

div.stage: She goes out .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Now you 've done it !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I could n't help it .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I do n't know .... They say there 's plenty of work on farms .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You can n't write if you work on a farm .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I can earn some more money and save . Other boys have worked their way through school and college . I can do that .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Of course — that is a way out of it . Yes ... of course ....Nathaniel opens the back doors and sees the thinnest crescent moon hanging in the sky .The new moon .... They say if you make a wish on the new moon it will come true .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You have to see it over your right shoulder .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You saw it over your right shoulder .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I do n't believe that , do you ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Well , suppose it were true , what would you wish ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You mean for right away ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: carefully looking over his right shoulder .I 'd wish to be with you .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: More than anything ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: More than being a writer or a theatre director or an actor ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Oh , yes , I 'm too young to start right away . I have to have an education first .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Suppose that wish could n't be , then what would you wish ?

lg.l: That you 'd write me long letters and let me write you long letters .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Are n't you going to tell John and Aunt Letitia good-bye ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No , sir . I do n't think I 'd better . Uncle John does n't care and Aunt Letitia will understand .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Yes , she always understands somehow .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Good-bye , sir .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Jonathan , suppose we go away together . I 'm not wanted and you 're not wanted .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You 're going to Paris to marry Mlle . Perrault !

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Would you let me be your father , Jonathan ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Sir ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You shall go to the schools where you will find the work you want .... Will you be my son ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do you like me that much ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I like you more than that much . You 'll get some long trousers and we 'll plan and plan . Suppose we run away together .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do you think we ought to leave some word , Uncle Nathaniel ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Of course . How stupid of me .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You write it .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No , we 'll both write it .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I do n't know what to say . I 've only run away once .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: So have I .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Did you ever run away ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Yes — when I was eighteen .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: taking up paperThe message ought to be short .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Why did you run away ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I wanted to write .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: You did !

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Did n't you know I ran away ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: No , sir ; they never would tell me what became of you .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: They did n't know .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: How could you keep it from them ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I changed my name — Mr. Alexander Jefferson , Sr ! What shall I say ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I can n't think .... Did Uncle John lock you in ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: No , I just ran away .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: How long did it take you to make up your mind to go ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I thought about it first when I was twelve . My father was still living then .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Did you go to Somerset School ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Yes — for three years .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: What did you do after you ran away ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: I had a very hard time , my boy — at first . I worked at anything I could get , then I got into a newspaper office , then I wrote “ autobiographies ” of famous men .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I thought you had to write your own autobiography —

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Not nowadays . Then I wrote some successful short stories , then some very successful long ones — and now I am independent ; but it took me ten bitter years to make my first success .... What shall I write here ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I never could think of things to say when I was going away .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Neither could I .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do n't you think “ good-bye ” would be enough ?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: writingCapital .... “ Good-Bye — Nathaniel . ” Now you sign it .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Signs“ Jonathan . ” ... Maybe we ought to put a line under it so Aunt Letitia wo n't feel so bad .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: makes a lineDear Aunt Letitia will understand . She is the blessed kind who always does . Now , where shall we put it ?... On John 's chair , and maybe he 'll understand too .

div.stage: He pins the note to John 's chair .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Do n't you want to pack your things ?

lg.l: On second thought , I 'll ask Aunt Letitia to send them .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Hello , Susan .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Jonathan , I just saw Miss Letitia and she was crying .... What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm going away , Susan .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Where are you going ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'm going with Uncle Nathaniel . I 'm going to be his son . And I 'm going to a fine prep . school and learn to write and do what I like .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: When are you coming back ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I do n't know . When I 'm older maybe .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Ca n't we write any more songs ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'll send some words to you in letters .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Will you write every week ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Yes .... Will you ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Yes . I wish I was going , too .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: So do I .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Maybe I 'll come to see you graduate .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: That will be fine !

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Good-bye , Susan .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: I can hardly wait until you graduate .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Neither can I .... Good-bye .

div.stage: Nathaniel enters .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: On third thought , I decided to wire for my things .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Good-bye , Mr. Nathaniel . I hope you 'll have a nice time .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Good-bye , Susan .

div.stage: He kisses her . She goes out .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: Good-bye , Susan .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: callingSend me some picture postcards , Jonathan .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I will .

div.stage: He watches her .

lg.l: Do n't you want to make your wish on the new moon , Jonathan ?

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I do n't know what to wish now . The only one I could think of has come true .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Good ... come , my boy .

sp.speaker: JONATHAN
sp.p: I 'll write a long letter to Susan Sample every week .

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: You can write her a long letter from New York .

lg.l: And I can send her picture postcards from every place we go to .
lg.stage: Arm in arm they go out talking .
